quote:
A time may come soon," said he, "when none will return. Then there will be need of valour without renown, for none shall remember the deeds that are done in the last defence of your homes. Yet the deeds will not be less valiant because they are unpraised."
She answered: "All your words are but to say: you are a woman, and your part is in the house. But when the men have died in battle and honour, you have leave to be burned in the house, for the men will need it no more. But I am of the House of Eorl and not a serving-woman. I can ride and wield blade, and I do not fear either pain or death."
"What do you fear, lady?" he asked.
"A cage," she said. "To stay behind bars, until use and old age accept them, and all chance of doing great deeds is gone beyond recall or desire.

His harp shall be restrung,
His halls shall echo golden
To songs of yore re-sung.

The woods shall wave on mountains.
And grass beneath the sun;
His wealth shall flow in fountains
And the rivers golden run.

The streams shall run in gladness,
The lakes shall shine and burn,
And sorrow fail and sadness
At the Mountain-king’s return!
summary: This poem describes the long-awaited return of a powerful "Mountain King," who rules over stone and silver. His comeback will bring about a glorious restoration: his rightful authority will be re-established, his ancient culture and songs will be revived, and his halls will echo with joy. The land will become incredibly prosperous, with wealth flowing like fountains and nature thriving. Most importantly, the Mountain King's return will banish all sorrow and sadness, ushering in a time of widespread happiness and gladness.

quote: Let him not vow to walk in the dark, who has not seen the nightfall.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Let him not vow to walk in the dark, who has not seen the nightfall.
summary: This quote advises caution against making commitments to difficult or unknown paths without first having even a basic understanding or experience of what those challenges entail. It means you shouldn't promise to endure great hardship or tackle a major challenge (walking in the dark) if you haven't even experienced the very beginning or a small taste of what that difficulty involves (seen the nightfall). Essentially, don't make a big vow about something tough unless you've had at least some initial insight into its nature, otherwise, you might be completely unprepared for the reality.

quote: The future, good or ill, was not forgotten, but ceased to have any power over the present. Health and hope grew strong in them, and they were content with each good day as it came, taking pleasure in every meal, and in every word and song.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: The future, good or ill, was not forgotten, but ceased to have any power over the present. summary: This quote describes a shift where people, while still aware of what the future might hold, no longer let worries or expectations about it control their current lives. This freedom allowed them to become healthier and more hopeful. As a result, they found deep contentment in each passing day, truly appreciating simple pleasures like every meal, conversation, and song.

quote: Out of the darkness of my life, so much frustrated, I put before you the one great thing to love on earth: the Blessed Sacrament … There you will find romance, glory, honour, fidelity, and the true way of all your loves upon earth.

quote: We all long for Eden, and we are constantly glimpsing it: our whole nature at its best and least corrupted, its gentlest and most human, is still soaked with the sense of exile.

However, even when humanity is at its most kind, gentle, and uncorrupted, there remains a deep, pervasive feeling of being separated or exiled from that ultimate perfection. It implies that this sense of longing and loss is an inherent part of the human condition, even in our finest moments.

quote: This is the ending. Now not day only shall be beloved, but night too shall be beautiful and blessed and all its fear pass away.

quote:

quote:

quote:
When evening in the Shire was grey
his footsteps on the Hill were heard;
before the dawn he went away
on journey long without a word.

From Wilderland to Western shore,
from northern waste to southern hill,
through dragon-lair and hidden door
and darkling woods he walked at will.

With Dwarf and Hobbit, Elves and Men,
with mortal and immortal folk,
with bird on bough and beast in den,
in their own secret tongues he spoke.

A deadly sword, a healing hand,
a back that bent beneath its load;
a trumpet-voice, a burning brand,
a weary pilgrim on the road.

A lord of wisdom throned he sat,
swift in anger, quick to laugh;
an old man in a battered hat
who leaned upon a thorny staff.

He stood upon the bridge alone
and Fire and Shadow both defied;
his staff was broken on the stone,
in Khazad-dûm his wisdom died.

He roamed all across Middle-earth, through wild and dangerous lands, and uniquely communicated with all beings – Dwarves, Hobbits, Elves, Men, and even animals. He was a man of many contradictions: a fierce warrior with a healing touch, a burdened leader who inspired others, yet also a weary pilgrim. Despite his great wisdom, he often appeared as a humble old man. The poem concludes by recounting his ultimate sacrifice, standing alone on a bridge to defy a great evil in Khazad-dûm, where his staff was broken and his wisdom, or life, seemed to end.

quote: Faerie is a perilous land, and in it are pitfalls for the unwary and dungeons for the overbold...The realm of fairy-story is wide and deep and high and filled with many things: all manner of beasts and birds are found there; shoreless seas and stars uncounted; beauty that is an enchantment, and an ever-present peril; both joy and sorrow as sharp as swords. In that realm a man may, perhaps, count himself fortunate to have wandered, but its very richness and strangeness tie the tongue of a traveller who would report them. And while he is there it is dangerous for him to ask too many questions, lest the gates should be shut and the keys be lost.

quote: For if joyful is the fountain that rises in the sun, its springs are in the wells of sorrow unfathomable at the foundations of the Earth.

It means that deep, almost immeasurable sadness, hidden like wells at the very foundations of the Earth, can be the fundamental source from which our happiness and beauty ultimately emerge. In essence, it highlights the idea that great joy can spring from deep pain.

quote:
Roads go ever ever on,

And under mountains of the moon.

Under cloud and under star,
Yet feet that wandering have gone
Turn at last to home afar.
Eyes that fire and sword have seen
And horror in the halls of stone
Look at last on meadows green
And trees and hills they long have known

It's a feeling that some things are just destined for an unhappy resolution.

quote: Yet such is oft the course of deeds that move the wheels of the world: small hands do them because they must, while the eyes of the great are elsewhere.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Yet such is oft the course of deeds that move the wheels of the world: small hands do them because they must, while the eyes of the great are elsewhere.

Instead, these crucial actions are frequently carried out by ordinary, often unrecognised individuals who do them out of necessity or duty. Meanwhile, those in positions of power and influence are often preoccupied with other matters, unaware of or simply not focused on the essential groundwork being laid by these less prominent people. It highlights how the real progress is often driven by the overlooked.

quote: The Dark Lord has Nine. But we have One, mightier than they: the White Rider. He has passed through the fire and the abyss, and they shall fear him. We will go where he leads.

quote: Why O why did I ever leave my hobbit-hole?" said poor Mr. Baggins, bumping up and down on Bombur's back.

quote: Handsome is as handsome does

Instead, it emphasizes that a person's character, actions, and how they behave are what truly define them as "handsome" or good. Someone who acts kindly, thoughtfully, and with integrity is considered genuinely appealing, regardless of how they look on the outside. In essence, it's your deeds and not your looks that truly matter.

quote: For it is easier to shout 'Stop!', than to do it.

It highlights the significant difference between simply voicing an opinion or command and the often-difficult work of implementation and execution. In essence, talking about a problem or a solution is always easier than putting in the effort to solve it.

quote:
Where are you going, Master?' cried Sam, though at last he understood what was happening.

'To the Havens, Sam,' said Frodo.

'And I can't come.'

'No, Sam. Not yet, anyway, not further than the Havens. Though you too were a Ring-bearer, if only for a little while. Your time may come. Do not be too sad, Sam. You cannot always be torn in two. You will have to be one and whole, for many years. You have so much to enjoy and to be, and to do.'

'But,' said Sam, and tears started in his eyes, 'I thought you were going to enjoy the Shire, too, for years and years, after all you have done.'

'So I thought too, once. But I have been too deeply hurt, Sam. I tried to save the Shire, and it has been saved, but not for me. It must often be so, Sam, when things are in danger: some one has to give them up, lose them, so that others may keep them. But you are my heir: all that I had and might have had I leave to you. And also you have Rose, and Elanor; and Frodo-lad will come, and Rosie-lass, and Merry, and Goldilocks, and Pippin; and perhaps more that I cannot see. Your hands and your wits will be needed everywhere. You will be the Mayor, of course, as long as you want to be, and the most famous gardener in history; and you will read things out of the Red Book, and keep alive the memory of the age that is gone, so that people will remember the Great Danger, and so love their beloved land all the more. And that will keep you as busy and as happy as anyone can be, as long as your part in the Story goes on.

'Come now, ride with me!

'But,' said Sam, and tears started in his eyes, 'I thought you were going to enjoy the Shire, too, for years and years, after all you have done.'

summary: This quote captures a poignant farewell between Frodo and Sam. Frodo reveals he is leaving for the Havens, a place of peace, because he has been too deeply wounded by his quest to save the Shire to truly enjoy it himself. He tells a heartbroken Sam that Sam cannot join him yet, as Sam has a vital and fulfilling life ahead in the Shire. Frodo entrusts Sam with his legacy, encouraging him to be whole, raise a family, serve as Mayor, become a renowned gardener, and keep the memory of their age alive. Frodo explains that he must give up the Shire for its salvation, but Sam's future there will be full of purpose and happiness.

quote: We set out to save the Shire, Sam and it has been saved - but not for me.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: We set out to save the Shire, Sam and it has been saved - but not for me.
summary: This quote means that the speaker and Sam successfully completed their difficult mission to save their home, the Shire, from danger. The Shire is now safe and secure, just as they intended. However, the speaker sadly realizes that despite their victory, they themselves won't be able to fully enjoy the peace and safety they worked so hard to achieve, implying a great personal cost or sacrifice.

quote: Why should a man be scorned, if, finding himself in prison, he tries to get out and go home? Or if, when he cannot do so, he thinks and talks about other topics than jailers and prison-walls? The world outside has not become less real because the prisoner cannot see it. In using Escape in this way the critics have chosen the wrong word, and, what is more, they are confusing, not always by sincere error, the Escape of the Prisoner with the Flight of the Deserter. just so a Party-spokesman might have labeled departure from the misery of the Fuhrer's or any other Reich and even criticism of it as treachery .... Not only do they confound the escape of the prisoner with the flight of the deserter; but they would seem to prefer the acquiescence of the "quisling" to the resistance of the patriot.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Why should a man be scorned, if, finding himself in prison, he tries to get out and go home? Or if, when he cannot do so, he thinks and talks about other topics than jailers and prison-walls? The world outside has not become less real because the prisoner cannot see it. In using Escape in this way the critics have chosen the wrong word, and, what is more, they are confusing, not always by sincere error, the Escape of the Prisoner with the Flight of the Deserter. just so a Party-spokesman might have labeled departure from the misery of the Fuhrer's or any other Reich and even criticism of it as treachery .... Not only do they confound the escape of the prisoner with the flight of the deserter; but they would seem to prefer the acquiescence of the "quisling" to the resistance of the patriot.
summary: J.R.R. Tolkien argues that it's wrong to criticize someone for wanting to escape a bad situation, just as it's natural for a prisoner to try to get out or at least think about the world beyond their cell. He emphasizes that the "outside world" of hope and imagination remains real, even if currently out of reach. Tolkien believes critics who condemn "escape" (especially in literature) are mistaken, wrongly confusing a prisoner's justified desire for freedom with the dishonorable act of a deserter abandoning their duty. He compares this misinterpretation to authoritarian regimes labeling any desire for change or criticism as treachery, concluding that such critics seem to prefer passive acceptance over active resistance and the pursuit of something better.

quote: I may be a burglar...but I'm an honest one, I hope, more or less.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: I may be a burglar...but I'm an honest one, I hope, more or less.
summary: This quote means that the speaker, despite being a burglar (someone who steals), believes they possess a certain level of personal integrity or honesty. They acknowledge their criminal profession but suggest they operate with a code of conduct or truthfulness, even if it's not perfect, as indicated by "I hope, more or less." Essentially, they see themselves as an "honest criminal," which is a bit of a paradox.

quote: Let this be the hour when we draw swords together. Fell deeds awake. Now for wrath, now for ruin, and the red dawn. Forth, Eorlingas!
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Let this be the hour when we draw swords together. Fell deeds awake. Now for wrath, now for ruin, and the red dawn. Forth, Eorlingas!
summary: This quote is a powerful rallying cry for war. It declares that the time has come for a united, fierce fight, warning that terrible, destructive events are about to unfold. Driven by anger, this conflict will lead to ruin, ushering in a new, bloody era. It ends with a direct command for the Eorlingas to charge forward into this intense battle.

quote: Many that live deserve death. And some that die deserve life. Can you give it to them? Then do not be too eager to deal out death in judgement. For even the very wise cannot see all ends.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Many that live deserve death. And some that die deserve life. Can you give it to them? Then do not be too eager to deal out death in judgement. For even the very wise cannot see all ends.
summary: This quote suggests that life isn't always fair: some truly bad people live on, while good people sometimes die too soon. Since you don't have the power to change who lives or dies, you shouldn't be too eager to judge others and decide they deserve death. Even the smartest people can't foresee all the consequences or truly understand the full story, so it's best to be humble and cautious when making such final judgments.

quote:
Farewell, and may the blessing of Elves and Men and all Free Folk go with you.
May the stars shine upon your faces!
prompt_template:
Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Farewell, and may the blessing of Elves and Men and all Free Folk go with you.
May the stars shine upon your faces!
summary: This quote is a warm and heartfelt farewell. It expresses a deep wish for the departing person to receive blessings and good fortune from all good people and creatures, like Elves and Men, in their journey. It also shares a beautiful hope that their future will be bright, happy, and guided, as if the stars themselves are shining directly upon them.

quote:
The world was fair, the mountains tall
In Elder Days before the fall...
prompt_template:
Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: The world was fair, the mountains tall
In Elder Days before the fall...
summary: This quote describes a time long ago, in the "Elder Days," when the world was a truly good and beautiful place, characterized by its fairness and majestic, tall mountains. It suggests an ideal, almost perfect era that existed before a significant event, referred to as "the fall," which presumably brought about a decline or loss of that original perfection. In essence, it speaks of a lost golden age.

quote:
Human stories are practically always about one thing, really, aren't they? Death. The inevitability of death. . .
. . . (quoting an obituary) 'There is no such thing as a natural death. Nothing that ever happens to man is natural, since his presence calls the whole world into question. All men must die, but for every man his death is an accident, and even if he knows it he would sense to it an unjustifiable violation.' Well, you may agree with the words or not, but those are the key spring of The Lord Of The Rings

Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Human stories are practically always about one thing, really, aren't they? Death. The inevitability of death. . .

All men must die, but for every man his death is an accident, and even if he knows it he would sense to it an unjustifiable violation.' Well, you may agree with the words or not, but those are the key spring of The Lord Of The Rings
summary: This quote explains that human stories are essentially about death and its unavoidable nature. It further argues that for humans, death isn't a "natural" event, but rather feels like an accident or an unfair violation, because human existence itself challenges the natural order of the world. This profound idea, that death is both inevitable yet feels deeply wrong and unnatural to humans, is presented as a central theme and inspiration for J.R.R. Tolkien's *The Lord of the Rings*.

quote:
The world has changed.
I see it in the water.
I feel it in the Earth.
I smell it in the air.
Much that once was is lost,
For none now live who remember it.
prompt_template:
Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: The world has changed.
I see it in the water.
I feel it in the Earth.
I smell it in the air.
Much that once was is lost,
For none now live who remember it.
summary: This quote expresses a profound sense that the world has undergone a major transformation. The speaker feels this change everywhere, observing it in the very elements of nature: water, earth, and air, indicating its pervasive reach. A significant part of what once existed has been lost, and crucially, no one alive today even remembers it. This suggests that the past is not just gone, but its very memory has vanished, making the change absolute and the former state truly forgotten.

quote: A man inherited a field in which was an accumulation of old stone, part of an older hall. Of the old stone some had already been used in building the house in which he actually lived, not far from the old house of his fathers. Of the rest he took some and built a tower. But his friends coming perceived at once (without troubling to climb the steps) that these stones had formerly belonged to a more ancient building. So they pushed the tower over, with no little labour, and in order to look for hidden carvings and inscriptions, or to discover whence the man's distant forefathers had obtained their building material. Some suspecting a deposit of coal under the soil began to dig for it, and forgot even the stones. They all said: 'This tower is most interesting.' But they also said (after pushing it over): 'What a muddle it is in!' And even the man's own descendants, who might have been expected to consider what he had been about, were heard to murmur: 'He is such an odd fellow! Imagine using these old stones just to build a nonsensical tower! Why did not he restore the old house? he had no sense of proportion.' But from the top of that tower the man had been able to look out upon the sea.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: A man inherited a field in which was an accumulation of old stone, part of an older hall. Of the old stone some had already been used in building the house in which he actually lived, not far from the old house of his fathers. Of the rest he took some and built a tower. But his friends coming perceived at once (without troubling to climb the steps) that these stones had formerly belonged to a more ancient building. So they pushed the tower over, with no little labour, and in order to look for hidden carvings and inscriptions, or to discover whence the man's distant forefathers had obtained their building material. Some suspecting a deposit of coal under the soil began to dig for it, and forgot even the stones. They all said: 'This tower is most interesting.' But they also said (after pushing it over): 'What a muddle it is in!' And even the man's own descendants, who might have been expected to consider what he had been about, were heard to murmur: 'He is such an odd fellow! Imagine using these old stones just to build a nonsensical tower! Why did not he restore the old house? he had no sense of proportion.' But from the top of that tower the man had been able to look out upon the sea.
summary: A man inherited land with old stones from an ancient building, some of which he had already used in his own house. He then used more of these stones to build a tower. His friends immediately recognized the stones were from an older structure and, without climbing, pushed the tower over to look for hidden carvings or to discover the stones' origins. Some even began digging for coal beneath the site, forgetting the stones entirely. While everyone found the tower "interesting," they also called it "a muddle" after its destruction. Even the man's own descendants criticized him, calling him "odd" for building a "nonsensical" tower instead of restoring an older family house. However, from the top of that tower, the man had been able to look out upon the sea.

quote:
I sang of leaves, of leaves of gold, and leaves of gold there grew:
Of wind I sang, a wind there came and in the branches blew.
Beyond the Sun, beyond the Moon, the foam was on the Sea,
And by the strand of Ilmarin there grew a Golden Tree.

Beneath the stars of Ever-eve in Eldamar it shone,
In Eldamar beside the walls of Elven Tirion.
There long the golden leaves have grown upon the branching years,
While here beyond the Sundering Seas now fall the Elven-tears.

O Lórien! Too long I have dwelt upon this Hither Shore
And in a fading crown have twined the golden elanor.
But if of ships I now would sing, what ship would come to me,
What ship would bear me ever back across so wide a Sea?

O Lórien! Too long I have dwelt upon this Hither Shore
And in a fading crown have twined the golden elanor.

What ship would bear me ever back across so wide a Sea?
summary: This poem describes a magical Golden Tree that the speaker's songs seem to bring to life in a beautiful, legendary elven land far beyond the sun and moon. This tree has stood bright and strong for ages in a place called Eldamar. However, the speaker is now in a different, sad place, feeling that they have been there too long and their own spirit or joy is fading. They express a deep longing to return to that glorious, golden home, wondering if any ship could ever carry them back across the vast sea that now separates them from it.

quote: Here was one with an air of high nobility such as Aragorn at times revealed, less high perhaps, yet also less incalculable and remote: one of the Kings of Men born into a later time, but touched with the wisdom and sadness of the Eldar Race. He knew now why Beregond spoke his name with love. He was a captain that men would follow, that he would follow, even under the shadow of the black wings.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Here was one with an air of high nobility such as Aragorn at times revealed, less high perhaps, yet also less incalculable and remote: one of the Kings of Men born into a later time, but touched with the wisdom and sadness of the Eldar Race. He knew now why Beregond spoke his name with love. He was a captain that men would follow, that he would follow, even under the shadow of the black wings.
summary: This quote describes a noble leader who, while perhaps not as grand or distant as Aragorn, is more approachable. He is a King of Men, but with the deep wisdom and a touch of the sadness often associated with the ancient Elves. This person inspires immense love and loyalty, so much so that people, including the narrator, would willingly follow him even into the most perilous situations.

quote:
For I am Saruman the Wise, Saruman Ring-maker, Saruman of Many Colours!'

I looked then and saw that his robes, which had seemed white, were not so, but were woven of all colours, and if he moved they shimmered and changed hue so that the eye was bewildered.

I liked white better,' I said.

White!' he sneered. 'It serves as a beginning. White cloth may be dyed. The white page can be overwritten; and the white light can be broken.'

In which case it is no longer white,' said I. 'And he that breaks a thing to find out what it is has left the path of wisdom.' - Gandalf
prompt_template:
Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: For I am Saruman the Wise, Saruman Ring-maker, Saruman of Many Colours!'

I looked then and saw that his robes, which had seemed white, were not so, but were woven of all colours, and if he moved they shimmered and changed hue so that the eye was bewildered.

I liked white better,' I said.

White!' he sneered. 'It serves as a beginning. White cloth may be dyed. The white page can be overwritten; and the white light can be broken.'

In which case it is no longer white,' said I. 'And he that breaks a thing to find out what it is has left the path of wisdom.' - Gandalf
summary: In this exchange, Saruman, who calls himself "of Many Colours," shows off his shimmering, multi-colored robes, explaining that simple white is merely a starting point that can be dyed, overwritten, or broken. He believes true power or wisdom comes from transforming or dissecting things. However, Gandalf prefers the purity of white, arguing that once something is broken or changed, it loses its original nature. He concludes by stating that someone who destroys something to understand it has strayed from true wisdom.

quote: Thus Aragorn for the first time in the full light of day beheld Éowyn, Lady of Rohan, and thought her fair, fair and cold, like a morning of pale spring that is not yet come to womanhood. And she was now suddenly aware of him: tall heir of kings, wise with many winters, greycloaked, hiding a power that yet she felt. For a moment still as stone she stood, then turning swiftly she was gone.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Thus Aragorn for the first time in the full light of day beheld Éowyn, Lady of Rohan, and thought her fair, fair and cold, like a morning of pale spring that is not yet come to womanhood. And she was now suddenly aware of him: tall heir of kings, wise with many winters, greycloaked, hiding a power that yet she felt. For a moment still as stone she stood, then turning swiftly she was gone.
summary: When Aragorn first saw Éowyn in broad daylight, he found her beautiful but also cold, like a young spring morning that hasn't fully bloomed. At the same time, Éowyn noticed him. She saw him as a tall, wise heir to kings, dressed in a grey cloak, and sensed a hidden power within him. For a brief moment, they both stood still, then Éowyn quickly turned and left.

quote: It seemed to him that he had stepped through a high window that looked on a vanished world. A light was upon it for which his language had no name. All that he saw was shapely, but the shapes seemed at once clear cut, as if they had been first conceived and drawn at the uncovering of his eyes, and ancient as if they had endured for ever. He saw no colour but those he knew, gold and white and blue and green, but they were fresh and poignant, as if he had at that moment first perceived them and made names for them new and wonderful. In winter here no heart could mourn for summer or for spring. No blemish or sickness or deformity could be seen in anything that grew upon the earth. On the land of Lorien there was no stain.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: It seemed to him that he had stepped through a high window that looked on a vanished world. A light was upon it for which his language had no name. All that he saw was shapely, but the shapes seemed at once clear cut, as if they had been first conceived and drawn at the uncovering of his eyes, and ancient as if they had endured for ever. summary: The quote describes someone entering a wondrous, almost forgotten world, as if stepping through a magical window. This place was bathed in an indescribable light, and everything in it appeared perfectly formed, feeling both ancient and brand new at the same time. Even familiar colors like gold, white, blue, and green seemed incredibly vivid and fresh, as if experienced for the very first time. It was a land of pure beauty, where no one grieved for passing seasons, and nothing showed any blemish, sickness, or imperfection.

quote: And yet their wills did not yield, and they struggled on.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: And yet their wills did not yield, and they struggled on.
summary: This quote means that even though the situation was tough or they faced great challenges, the people involved refused to give up their determination. They kept their strong will and continued to push forward and work hard, despite the difficulty.

quote: True courage is about knowing not when to take a life, but when to spare one.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: True courage is about knowing not when to take a life, but when to spare one.
summary: This quote suggests that genuine bravery isn't about knowing when it's necessary or justified to end a life. Instead, true courage lies in the wisdom and strength to choose to preserve a life, even when you have the power or opportunity to take it. It emphasizes that real bravery is found in compassion, restraint, and the decision to protect rather than destroy.

quote: out of the frying pan and into the fire
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: out of the frying pan and into the fire
summary: The idiom "out of the frying pan and into the fire" describes a situation where someone escapes from a bad or difficult circumstance, only to find themselves immediately in an even worse or more dangerous predicament. It means moving from one undesirable situation directly into another that is far more troublesome or severe. Essentially, it illustrates an unfortunate progression where an attempt to escape a problem leads to a greater one.

quote: Few other griefs amid the ill chances of this world have more bitterness and shame for a man's heart than to behold the love of a lady so fair and brave that cannot be returned.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Few other griefs amid the ill chances of this world have more bitterness and shame for a man's heart than to behold the love of a lady so fair and brave that cannot be returned.
summary: This quote suggests that one of the most painful and humiliating experiences a man can face is realizing that a wonderful woman deeply loves him, but he is unable to return those feelings. It brings a unique kind of bitterness and shame to his heart because he sees the genuine affection of someone truly admirable, yet cannot give back the love she deserves. According to the quote, few other misfortunes in life cause as much emotional distress as this specific situation.

quote:
Farewell sweet earth and northern sky,
for ever blest, since here did lie
and here with lissom limbs did run
beneath the Moon, beneath the Sun,
Lúthien Tinúviel
more fair than Mortal tongue can tell.
Though all to ruin fell the world
and were dissolved and backward hurled;
unmade into the old abyss,
yet were its making good, for this―
the dusk, the dawn, the earth, the sea―
that Lúthien for a time should be.

Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Farewell sweet earth and northern sky,

and were dissolved and backward hurled;

that Lúthien for a time should be.
summary: The speaker bids farewell to the world, calling it forever blessed because Lúthien Tinúviel, a being of unimaginable beauty, once lived and ran there. Even if the entire world were to crumble into ruin and be completely unmade, its creation would still have been worthwhile. This is because the very existence of the world – its dusk, dawn, earth, and sea – allowed Lúthien to exist, even if only for a time. Her presence alone justified the world's making.

quote: For nothing is evil in the beginning.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: For nothing is evil in the beginning.
summary: This quote suggests that nothing is born or created with inherent badness or wickedness. Instead, everything begins in a neutral, pure, or even good state. Evil is not a fundamental part of existence from the start, but rather something that develops, is chosen, or emerges over time through actions, corruption, or circumstances. It implies that harmfulness is an acquired characteristic, not an original one.

quote: Do you remember the Shire, Mr. Frodo? It'll be spring soon. And the orchards will be in blossom. And the birds will be nesting in the hazel thicket. And they'll be sowing the summer barley in the lower fields... and eating the first of the strawberries with cream. Do you remember the taste of strawberries?
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Do you remember the Shire, Mr. Frodo? It'll be spring soon. And the orchards will be in blossom. And the birds will be nesting in the hazel thicket. And they'll be sowing the summer barley in the lower fields... and eating the first of the strawberries with cream. Do you remember the taste of strawberries?
summary: In this quote, Samwise Gamgee tries to comfort Frodo by reminding him of their peaceful home, the Shire. He paints a hopeful picture of spring arriving there soon, with orchards blossoming, birds nesting, and farmers planting barley. Most vividly, he recalls the simple pleasure of eating fresh strawberries with cream, asking Frodo if he remembers their taste. Sam's words are meant to offer Frodo a comforting vision of home and the simple joys they long to return to, providing a stark contrast to their current difficult journey.

quote:
Hinder me? Thou fool. No living man may hinder me!"
Then Merry heard in all sounds of the hour the strangest. It seemed that Dernhelm laughed, and the clear voice was like the ring of steel.
"But no living man am I! You are looking upon a woman. Eowyn am I, Eomund's daughter. You stand between me and my lord and kin. Begone, if you be not deathless! For living or dark undead, I will smite you, if you touch him."
The winged creature screamed at her, but then the Ringwraith was silent, as if in sudden doubt. Very amazement for a moment conquered Merry's fear. He opened his eyes and the blackness was lifted from them. There some paces from him sat the great beast, and all seemed dark about it, and above it loomed the Nazgul Lord like a shadow of despair. A little to the left facing them stood whom he had called Dernhelm. But the helm of her secrecy had fallen from her, and and her bright hair, released from its bonds, gleamed with pale gold upon her shoulders. Her eyes grey as the sea were hard and fell, and yet tears gleamed in them. A sword was in her hand, and she raised her shield against the horror of her enemy's eyes.

The winged creature screamed at her, but then the Ringwraith was silent, as if in sudden doubt. Very amazement for a moment conquered Merry's fear. He opened his eyes and the blackness was lifted from them. There some paces from him sat the great beast, and all seemed dark about it, and above it loomed the Nazgul Lord like a shadow of despair. A little to the left facing them stood whom he had called Dernhelm. But the helm of her secrecy had fallen from her, and and her bright hair, released from its bonds, gleamed with pale gold upon her shoulders. Her eyes grey as the sea were hard and fell, and yet tears gleamed in them. A sword was in her hand, and she raised her shield against the horror of her enemy's eyes.

However, the warrior known as Dernhelm then reveals herself to be Eowyn, a woman, challenging his boast by stating, "But no living man am I!" She defiantly tells him that she stands between him and her lord and kin, vowing to fight him if he dares to touch them. The Witch-king is momentarily stunned and silent, while Merry, watching, is amazed to see Eowyn unveiled, her golden hair and determined, tear-filled eyes showing her fierce resolve as she stands ready with her sword and shield against the terrifying enemy.

quote: No taste of food, no feel of water, no sound of wind, no memory of tree or grass or flower, no image of moon or star are left to me. I am naked in the dark, Sam, and there is no veil between me and the wheel of fire. I begin to see it even with my waking eyes, and all else fades.

I am naked in the dark, Sam, and there is no veil between me and the wheel of fire. I begin to see it even with my waking eyes, and all else fades.
summary: The speaker describes a complete and terrifying loss of everything that brought comfort or joy. They can no longer taste food, feel water, hear the wind, or remember any beauty from nature or the sky. This leaves them feeling utterly exposed and vulnerable, as if they are naked in the dark with nothing to protect them. They are now directly confronted by a terrible, overwhelming torment – the "wheel of fire" – which is becoming clearer and more real even to their waking eyes, making everything else in their world fade away.

quote: Don’t adventures ever have an end? I suppose not. Someone else always has to carry on the story.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Don’t adventures ever have an end? I suppose not. Someone else always has to carry on the story.
summary: This quote reflects the idea that important journeys or stories don't ever truly finish with just one person. The speaker realizes that even if their own part in an adventure ends, the larger story or quest will continue, as someone else will always step in to take up the task and carry it forward. It's about the ongoing nature of a mission or legacy that extends beyond any single individual.

quote:
What do you fear, lady?' he asked.

'A cage,' she said.
prompt_template:
Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: What do you fear, lady?' he asked.

'A cage,' she said.
summary: This short exchange describes a man asking a woman about her deepest fear. Her response, "A cage," reveals that she is not afraid of something tangible like a monster, but rather the loss of freedom and being trapped. Her greatest dread is the idea of being confined, restricted, or having her choices limited, much like an animal kept in a cage.

quote:
Don't the great tales never end?"
"No, they never end as tales," said Frodo. "But the people in them come, and go when their part's ended. Our part will end later – or sooner.
prompt_template:
Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Don't the great tales never end?"
"No, they never end as tales," said Frodo. "But the people in them come, and go when their part's ended. Our part will end later – or sooner.
summary: This quote explains that while great stories or legends themselves live on forever, the people who are part of those stories do not. Frodo clarifies that the *tales* never truly end, but the individuals within them only play a specific role for a certain period. Once their part is finished, they move on, acknowledging that their own time in the ongoing story of life will also eventually come to an end.

quote: the most improper job of any man, even saints (who at any rate were at least unwilling to take it on), is bossing other men. Not one in a million is fit for it, and least of all those who seek the opportunity.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: the most improper job of any man, even saints (who at any rate were at least unwilling to take it on), is bossing other men. Not one in a million is fit for it, and least of all those who seek the opportunity.
summary: This quote argues that being in charge of others is a deeply unsuitable job for anyone. Even highly virtuous people avoid this role, suggesting it's something no one should aspire to. The author believes that hardly anyone is truly fit to lead or boss others, and, ironically, the people who are most eager to take on such a position are actually the least qualified for it.

quote:
Though here at journey's end I lie
In darkness buried deep,
Beyond all towers strong and high,
Beyond all mountains steep,
Above all shadows rides the Sun
And Stars for ever dwell:
I will not say the Day is done,
Nor bid the Stars farewell.
prompt_template:
Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Though here at journey's end I lie
In darkness buried deep,
Beyond all towers strong and high,
Beyond all mountains steep,
Above all shadows rides the Sun
And Stars for ever dwell:
I will not say the Day is done,
Nor bid the Stars farewell.
summary: Even though the speaker is at the very end of their life, lying buried in deep darkness, far away from the grand and impressive things of the living world, they still recognize a powerful truth. They observe that the Sun continues to shine above all shadows and the Stars dwell forever in the sky. Because of this enduring light and presence, the speaker refuses to declare that everything is truly over, nor will they say goodbye to the hope and continuity that the stars represent.

quote: It must often be so, Sam, when things are in danger: some one has to give them up, lose them, so that others may keep them.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: It must often be so, Sam, when things are in danger: some one has to give them up, lose them, so that others may keep them.
summary: This quote suggests that when something important is in danger, a difficult choice often has to be made. It means that one person or group might have to give up or lose something valuable—a possession, a right, or even their life—so that others can keep, protect, or benefit from that very thing. Essentially, it highlights the idea of a necessary sacrifice by some for the preservation and well-being of others.

quote: It is wisdom to recognize necessity when all other courses have been weighed, though as folly it may appear to those who cling to false hope.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: It is wisdom to recognize necessity when all other courses have been weighed, though as folly it may appear to those who cling to false hope.
summary: True wisdom means understanding and accepting what *must* be done, but only after you've thoroughly considered and exhausted all other possible options. While this decision might appear foolish or like giving up to people who are still clinging to false hope, it is actually a sign of good judgment to face reality when all other paths have proven unsuccessful.

quote:
Tomorrow we may come this way,
And take the hidden paths that run
Towards the Moon or to the Sun
prompt_template:
Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Tomorrow we may come this way,
And take the hidden paths that run
Towards the Moon or to the Sun
summary: This quote suggests that even if we find ourselves in a familiar situation or place in the future, we might choose to explore new, less obvious paths. These "hidden paths" represent opportunities to pursue incredibly ambitious, perhaps even fantastical, goals – aiming for the extreme limits of what's possible, rather than sticking to the familiar or expected. It speaks to a desire for adventure, a willingness to take unconventional routes, and the pursuit of vast, perhaps even contradictory, dreams.

quote: One tiny Hobbit against all the evil the world could muster. A sane being would have given up, but Samwise burned with a magnificent madness, a glowing obsession to surmount every obstacle, to find Frodo, destroy the Ring, and cleanse Middle Earth of its festering malignancy. He knew he would try again. Fail, perhaps. And try once more. A thousand, thousand times if need be, but he would not give up the quest.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: One tiny Hobbit against all the evil the world could muster. A sane being would have given up, but Samwise burned with a magnificent madness, a glowing obsession to surmount every obstacle, to find Frodo, destroy the Ring, and cleanse Middle Earth of its festering malignancy. He knew he would try again. Fail, perhaps. And try once more. A thousand, thousand times if need be, but he would not give up the quest.
summary: The quote highlights that Samwise, a small Hobbit, faced an overwhelming amount of evil that would have made any sensible person give up. However, Sam was fueled by an extraordinary, almost obsessive determination to overcome every obstacle. His unwavering goal was to find Frodo, destroy the powerful Ring, and rid Middle-earth of its deep corruption. He was prepared to try repeatedly, even if he failed countless times, because he was absolutely determined never to abandon his vital quest.

quote:
And you, Ring-bearer,’ she said, turning to Frodo. ‘I come to you last who are not last in my thoughts. For you I have prepared this.’ She held up a small crystal phial: it glittered as she moved it, and rays of white light sprang from her hand. ‘In this phial,’ she said, ‘is caught the light of Eärendil’s star, set amid the waters of my fountain. It will shine still brighter when night is about you. May it be a light to you in dark places, when all other lights go out. Remember Galadriel and her Mirror!’

Frodo took the phial, and for a moment as it shone between them, he saw her again standing like a queen, great and beautiful.

She presented him with a small crystal bottle, or phial, which contained the light of Eärendil's star mixed with water from her fountain. She explained that this light would shine brightest in darkness, serving as a guide for him in the most desperate and dark places, when all other lights and hopes had faded. She urged him to remember her and her wisdom. As Frodo took the glowing phial, he saw Galadriel standing before him like a majestic and beautiful queen.

quote: I'm going on an adventure!
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: I'm going on an adventure!
summary: This quote means the person is very excited about starting a new journey or experience that will be different from their usual routine. They are looking forward to exploring new places, facing new challenges, and discovering new things. It shows they are full of enthusiasm and ready to embark on something significant and thrilling.

quote: There is no curse in Elvish, Entish, or the tongues of Men for this treachery.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: There is no curse in Elvish, Entish, or the tongues of Men for this treachery.
summary: This quote means that the act of treachery committed was so incredibly awful and beyond forgiveness that no existing language, whether spoken by magical beings or humans, has words strong enough to truly curse or condemn it. The betrayal was so profound that it surpasses any known way to express its wickedness.

quote: Then, Éowyn of Rohan, I say to you that you are beautiful. In the valleys of our hills there are flowers fair and bright, and maidens fairer still; but neither flower nor lady have I seen till now in Gondor so lovely, and so sorrowful. It may be that only a few days are left ere darkness falls upon our world, and when it comes I hope to face it steadily; but it would ease my heart, if while the Sun yet shines, I could see you still. For you and I have both passed under the wings of the Shadow, and the same hand drew us back.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Then, Éowyn of Rohan, I say to you that you are beautiful. For you and I have both passed under the wings of the Shadow, and the same hand drew us back.
summary: The speaker tells Éowyn that she is exceptionally beautiful, more so than any other person or flower he has seen in Gondor, and notes that her beauty is uniquely combined with sorrow. He acknowledges that their world faces impending darkness and he hopes to face it bravely, but seeing her while there is still light would bring him great comfort. He explains that they share a deep bond because they have both experienced a terrible encounter with a great evil (the Shadow) and were rescued from its power.

quote: Love not too well the work of thy hands and the devices of thy heart; and remember that the true hope of the Noldor lieth in the West, and cometh from the Sea.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Love not too well the work of thy hands and the devices of thy heart; and remember that the true hope of the Noldor lieth in the West, and cometh from the Sea.
summary: This quote advises the Noldor, a group of people, not to become too attached to or overly proud of the things they create with their hands or the plans and desires they devise in their hearts. It warns them against placing their ultimate hope or faith in their own achievements or ambitions. Instead, it reminds them that their true hope and salvation lie in the West and will come to them from the Sea, suggesting that their ultimate well-being depends on an external source of aid or a return to a different, perhaps blessed, place, rather than solely on their own efforts or creations.

quote:
Although now long estranged,
Man is not wholly lost nor wholly changed.
Dis-graced he may be, yet is not de-throned,
and keeps the rags of lordship once he owned:
Man, Sub-creator, the refracted Light
through whom is splintered from a single White
to many hues, and endlessly combined
in living shapes that move from mind to mind.
Though all the crannies of the world we filled
with Elves and Goblins, though we dared to build
Gods and their houses out of dark and light,
and sowed the seed of dragons- 'twas our right
(used or misused). That right has not decayed:
we make still by the law in which we're made.

Fantasy remains a human right: we make in our measure and in our derivative mode, because we are made: and not only made, but made in the image and likeness of a Maker.

through whom is splintered from a single White
to many hues, and endlessly combined

and sowed the seed of dragons- 'twas our right
(used or misused). That right has not decayed:
we make still by the law in which we're made.

Fantasy remains a human right: we make in our measure and in our derivative mode, because we are made: and not only made, but made in the image and likeness of a Maker.
summary: Even though humanity might seem flawed or fallen, we haven't lost our core nature or our inherent dignity. We are called "Sub-creators" because we reflect a greater Creator, much like a single light source can splinter into many colors. This innate ability is why we've always imagined and brought to life things like Elves, Goblins, and Dragons. This power to create and tell stories isn't just a pastime; it's a fundamental human right that hasn't diminished. We are able to create new worlds and narratives because we ourselves were made in the image of a Maker, and this inherent connection allows us to continue making in our own way.

quote:
Why, Sam, he said, to hear you somehow makes me as merry as if the
story was already written. But you’ve left out one of the chief characters; Samwise the stout hearted. ‘I want to hear more about Sam, dad. Why didn’t they put in more of his talk, dad? That’s what I like, it makes me laugh. And Frodo wouldn’t have got far without Sam, would he, dad?’ 

Now, Mr. Frodo, said Sam, you shouldn’t make fun. I was serious.

So was I, said Frodo, and so I am. We’re going on a bit too fast. You and
I, Sam, are still stuck in the worst places of the story, and it is all too likely that some will say at this point ‘Shut the book now, dad; we don’t want to read any more’.

Maybe, said Sam, but I wouldn’t be one to say that. Things done and
over and made into part of the great tales are different. Why, even Gollum might be good in a tale, better than he is to have by you, anyway. And he used to like tales himself once, by his own account. I wonder if he thinks he’s the hero or the villain?
Gollum! he called. Would you like to be the hero, now where’s he got to
again?

Gollum! he called. Would you like to be the hero, now where’s he got to

summary: This passage captures a conversation about storytelling and perspective. It begins with a child expressing their love for Samwise Gamgee, wanting more of his dialogue in the story and highlighting his essential role in Frodo's journey. Sam, initially thinking Frodo is joking, is corrected as Frodo explains that they are still living through the difficult, unglamorous parts of their adventure, fearing readers might give up. Sam, however, offers a different view, believing that once events become a "great tale," they change, making even a character like Gollum interesting. He then wonders aloud if Gollum sees himself as a hero or a villain in his own story.

quote: Frodo was now safe in the Last Homely House east of the Sea. That house was, as Bilbo had long ago reported, ‘a perfect house, whether you like food or sleep, or story-telling or singing, or just sitting and thinking best, or a pleasant mixture of them all.’ Merely to be there was a cure for weariness, fear and sadness.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Frodo was now safe in the Last Homely House east of the Sea. summary: Frodo finally found safety at the Last Homely House, a place Bilbo had described as perfect. This house offered comfort and delight for anyone, whether they preferred eating, sleeping, telling stories, singing, or simply quiet thinking. Just being there was enough to cure weariness, fear, and sadness.

quote: Nobody believes me when I say that my long book is an attempt to create a world in which a form of language agreeable to my personal aesthetic might seem real. But it is true.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Nobody believes me when I say that my long book is an attempt to create a world in which a form of language agreeable to my personal aesthetic might seem real. But it is true.
summary: The author feels misunderstood, as people don't believe their true reason for writing such a long book. They explain that their real goal is to create an entire fictional world within the book where their own unique and preferred style of language can feel completely natural and believable. Despite the skepticism, the author insists that this specific creative aim is genuinely true.

quote: The world isn't in your books and maps, it's out there.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: The world isn't in your books and maps, it's out there.
summary: This quote means that you can't truly understand the world just by reading books or looking at maps. While these provide information, the actual world with all its real experiences is found by stepping outside and engaging with it directly. It's a simple reminder that genuine knowledge comes from firsthand experience, not just from what you learn on paper.

quote: If more of us valued food and cheer and song above hoarded gold, it would be a merrier world. But, sad or merry, I must leave it now. Farewell. - Thorin
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: If more of us valued food and cheer and song above hoarded gold, it would be a merrier world. But, sad or merry, I must leave it now. Farewell. - Thorin
summary: Thorin expresses his belief that the world would be a much happier place if people prioritized simple joys like good food, companionship, and music over the selfish accumulation of wealth. He shares this profound thought as he faces his own death, accepting that he must now leave the world, regardless of whether it remains a sorrowful or joyful place.

quote: Pippin glanced in some wonder at the face now close beside his own, for the sound of that laugh had been gay and merry. Yet in the wizard's face he saw at first only lines of care and sorrow; though as he looked more intently he perceived that under all there was a great joy: a fountain of mirth enough to set a kingdom laughing, were it to gush forth.

summary: Pippin was surprised because the wizard's laugh sounded very happy and cheerful, even though the wizard's face initially appeared full of worry and sadness. However, as Pippin looked more closely, he realized that deep beneath the surface, the wizard held a vast amount of hidden joy. This inner happiness was so immense, it was like a fountain of cheer powerful enough to make an entire kingdom laugh if it were to fully burst forth.

quote:

quote:
Despair, or folly?' said Gandalf. 'It is not despair, for despair is only for those who see the end beyond all doubt. We do not. It is wisdom to recognize necessity, when all other courses have been weighed, though as folly it may appear to those who cling to false hope. Well, let folly be our cloak, a veil before the eyes of the Enemy! For he is very wise, and weighs all things to a nicety in the scales of his malice. But the only measure that he knows is desire, desire for power; and so he judges all hearts. Into his heart the thought will not enter that any will refuse it, that having the Ring we may seek to destroy it. If we seek this, we shall put him out of reckoning.'
'At least for a while,' said Elrond. 'The road must be trod, but it will be very hard. And neither strenght nor wisdom will carry us far upon it. This quest may be attempted by the weak with as much hope as the strong. Yet such is oft the course of deeds that move the wheels of the world: small hands do them because they must, while the eyes of the great are elsewhere.

Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Despair, or folly?' said Gandalf. 'It is not despair, for despair is only for those who see the end beyond all doubt. We do not. Well, let folly be our cloak, a veil before the eyes of the Enemy! For he is very wise, and weighs all things to a nicety in the scales of his malice. But the only measure that he knows is desire, desire for power; and so he judges all hearts. Into his heart the thought will not enter that any will refuse it, that having the Ring we may seek to destroy it. If we seek this, we shall put him out of reckoning.'
'At least for a while,' said Elrond. 'The road must be trod, but it will be very hard. And neither strenght nor wisdom will carry us far upon it. This quest may be attempted by the weak with as much hope as the strong. Yet such is oft the course of deeds that move the wheels of the world: small hands do them because they must, while the eyes of the great are elsewhere.
summary: Gandalf explains that their difficult decision isn't born of despair, as they still hold hope. He argues it's wise to accept a necessary, hard path, even if it appears foolish to others who cling to false hope. This seeming 'folly' can serve as a disguise against the Enemy, who only understands the desire for power and will never expect them to try and destroy the Ring rather than use it. Elrond agrees the task will be incredibly difficult, but notes that such world-changing deeds are often accomplished by the seemingly weak or insignificant, precisely because the powerful are looking elsewhere.

quote:
For she is a fair maiden, fairest lady of a house of queens. And yet I know not how I should speak of her. When I first looked on her and perceived her unhappiness, it seemed to me that I saw a white flower standing straight and proud, shapely as a lily, and yet knew that it was hard, as if wrought by elf-wrights out of steel. Or was it, maybe, a frost that had turned its sap to ice, and so it stood, bitter-sweet, still fair to see, but stricken, soon to fall and die?
- Aragorn about Éowyn

summary: Aragorn describes Éowyn as a woman of great beauty and noble lineage, yet he finds it difficult to truly understand her. He immediately sensed her deep unhappiness. To him, she appeared like a beautiful, proud lily, outwardly strong and dignified. However, he also perceived an unyielding hardness within her, as if her spirit were forged from steel by magical beings. Alternatively, he wondered if her inner essence had been frozen by hardship, leaving her beautiful but deeply wounded, perhaps on the verge of despair and death.

quote: We are plain quiet folk, and I have no use for adventures. Nasty, disturbing, and uncomfortable things.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: We are plain quiet folk, and I have no use for adventures. Nasty, disturbing, and uncomfortable things.
summary: This quote means that the speaker and their companions are ordinary, peaceful people who strongly dislike adventures. They see adventures as unpleasant, unsettling, and uncomfortable experiences that disrupt their quiet way of life. Essentially, they prefer a calm, predictable existence over any kind of excitement or trouble.

quote:
Through Rohan over fen and field where the long grass grows
The West Wind goes walking, and about the walls it goes.
What news from the West, oh wandering wind, do you bring to me tonight?
Have you seen Boromir the Tall by moon or by starlight?
‘I saw him ride over seven streams, over waters wide and grey;
I saw him walk in empty lands, until he passed away
Into the shadows of the North. I saw him then no more.
The North Wind may have heard the horn of the son of Denethor.’
Oh, Boromir! From the high walls westward I looked afar.
But you came not from the empty lands where no men are.

From the mouth of the sea the South Wind flies,
From the sand hills and the stones;
The wailing of the gulls it bears, and at the gate it moans
What news from the South, oh sighing wind, do you bring to me at eve?
Where now is Boromir the Fair? He tarries and I grieve.
‘Ask me not where he doth dwell--so many bones there lie
On the white shores and on the black shores under the stormy sky;
So many have passed down Anduin to find the flowing sea.
Ask of the North Wind news of them the North Wind sends to me!’
Oh Boromir! Beyond the gate the Seaward road runs South,
But you came not with the wailing gulls from the grey seas mouth.

From the Gate of Kings the North Wind rides,
And past the roaring falls
And loud and cold about the Tower its loud horn calls.
What news from the North, oh mighty wind, do you bring to me today?
What news of Boromir the Bold? For he is long away.
‘Beneath Amon Hen I heard his cry. There many foes he fought
His cloven shield, his broken sword, they to the water brought.
His head so proud, his face so fair, his limbs they laid to rest;
And Rauros, Golden Rauros Falls, bore him upon its breast.’
Oh Boromir! The Tower of Guard shall ever northward gaze
To Rauros, Golden Rauros Falls until the end of days.

summary: This poem is a mournful lament from a speaker desperately seeking news of Boromir. They question the West Wind, which offers vague information, suggesting Boromir passed away into the North. Next, they ask the South Wind, which hints at many lost lives but directs the speaker to the North Wind for specific news. Finally, the North Wind reveals Boromir's heroic fate: he fought bravely against many foes at Amon Hen, where he fell, and his body was carried by the majestic Rauros Falls. The poem concludes with the speaker's enduring grief and a promise to forever look northward in remembrance of Boromir.

quote: Fear nothing! Have peace until the morning! Heed no nightly noises!
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Fear nothing! Have peace until the morning! Heed no nightly noises!
summary: This quote encourages you to let go of all fear and find a deep sense of peace that lasts through the night. It advises you to ignore any disturbances or worries that might arise in the darkness, allowing you to rest calmly without being bothered by external sounds or internal anxieties.

quote: Thief, thief, thief! Baggins! We hates it, we hates it, we hates it forever!
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Thief, thief, thief! Baggins! We hates it, we hates it, we hates it forever!
summary: This quote expresses intense anger and resentment towards someone named Baggins, who is repeatedly called a "thief." The speaker, likely Gollum, is furious because Baggins has taken something precious from them. Their hatred for Baggins and the act of theft is so profound and deeply felt that they declare it will last forever, showing an inability to forgive or forget the perceived wrong.

quote: Your lullaby would waken a drunken goblin!
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Your lullaby would waken a drunken goblin!
summary: This humorous but harsh quote means that someone's singing, especially their "lullaby," is incredibly bad and un-soothing. Instead of being gentle and putting someone to sleep as a lullaby should, their voice is so loud, off-key, or unpleasant that it would actually wake up even the most deeply asleep and unresponsive person, like a very drunk goblin who would normally be impossible to rouse. Essentially, it's a way of saying their singing is terrible and disruptive.

quote: Fantasy is escapist, and that is its glory. If a soldier is imprisoned by the enemy, don't we consider it his duty to escape?
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Fantasy is escapist, and that is its glory. If a soldier is imprisoned by the enemy, don't we consider it his duty to escape?
summary: This quote argues that while fantasy does allow people to escape from reality, this isn't a flaw but actually its greatest strength. It compares this act of "escaping" through fantasy to a soldier who is imprisoned by the enemy: just as we would expect and even consider it the soldier's duty to escape their confinement, the quote suggests that using fantasy to mentally get away from life's difficulties is a good and even necessary thing to do.

quote: Here you find us sitting on a field of victory, amid the plunder of armies, and you wonder how we came by a few well-earned comforts!
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Here you find us sitting on a field of victory, amid the plunder of armies, and you wonder how we came by a few well-earned comforts!

They are essentially saying, "We've just won a major conflict and are surrounded by all the valuable things we took from the defeated. Given this, it should be obvious that our current comforts and wealth come directly from the spoils of our victory, so why are you even asking?"

quote: Not all those who wander are lost
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Not all those who wander are lost
summary: This quote challenges the common belief that anyone not following a clear, pre-determined path must be confused, aimless, or without purpose. It suggests that someone who appears to be "wandering" – exploring different ideas, taking unconventional routes, or not having an immediate fixed destination – might actually be doing so intentionally. They could be on a journey of discovery, learning, or self-exploration, and this unconventional path may lead them to exactly where they need to be, even if it wasn't the way others expected. In essence, not having a straight-line plan doesn't mean you're lost; sometimes, the journey of exploration is the purpose itself.

quote: For you little gardener and lover of trees, I have only a small gift. Here is set G for Galadriel, but it may stand for garden in your tongue. In this box there is earth from my orchard, and such blessing as Galadriel has still to bestow is upon it. It will not keep you on your road, nor defend you against any peril; but if you keep it and see your home again at last, then perhaps it may reward you. Though you should find all barren and laid waste, there will be few gardens in Middle-earth that will bloom like your garden, if you sprinkle this earth there. quote: But of bliss and glad life there is little to be said, before it ends; as works fair and wonderful, while they still endure for eyes to see, are ever their own record, and only when they are in peril or broken for ever do they pass into song.

It's only when these good times or wonderful things are in danger or completely gone forever that we truly start to appreciate them, remember them, and tell stories or "sing songs" about them.

quote:
The Balrog reached the bridge. Gandalf stood in the middle of the span, leaning on the staff in his left hand, but in his other hand Glamdring gleamed, cold and white. His enemy halted again, facing him, and the shadow about it reached out like two vast wings. It raised the whip, and the thongs whined and cracked. Fire came from its nostrils. But Gandalf stood firm.

'You cannot pass,' he said. The orcs stood still, and a dead silence fell. 'I am a servant of the Secret Fire, wielder of the flame of Anor. You cannot pass. The dark fire will not avail you, flame of Udûn. Go back to the Shadow! You cannot pass.'

The Balrog made no answer. The fire in it seemed to die, but the darkness grew. It stepped forward slowly onto the bridge, and suddenly it drew itself up to a great height, and its wings were spread from wall to wall; but still Gandalf could be seen, glimmering in the gloom; he seemed small, and altogether alone: grey and bent, like a wizened tree before the onset of a storm.

From out of the shadow a red sword leaped flaming.

Glamdring glittered white in answer.

There was a ringing clash and a stab of white fire. The Balrog fell back and its sword flew up in molten fragments. The wizard swayed on the bridge, stepped back a pace, and then again stood still.

'You cannot pass!' he said.

With a bound the Balrog leaped full upon the bridge. Its whip whirled and hissed.

'He cannot stand alone!' cried Aragorn suddenly and ran back along the bridge. 'Elendil!' he shouted. 'I am with you, Gandalf!'

'Gondor!' cried Boromir and leaped after him.

At that moment Gandalf lifted his staff, and crying aloud he smote the bridge before him. The staff broke asunder and fell from his hand. A blinding sheet of white flame sprang up. The bridge cracked. Right at the Balrog's feet it broke, and the stone upon which it stood crashed into the gulf, while the rest remained, poised, quivering like a tongue of rock thrust out into emptiness.

With a terrible cry the Balrog fell forward, and its shadow plunged down and vanished. But even as it fell it swung its whip, and the thongs lashed and curled about the wizard's knees, dragging him to the brink. He staggered and fell, grasped vainly at the stone, and slid into the abyss. 'Fly, you fools!' he cried, and was gone.

summary: On a narrow bridge, the wizard Gandalf bravely confronted the monstrous Balrog, declaring it could not pass. Despite the creature's menacing display of fire and whip, Gandalf stood firm and engaged it in battle, shattering its flaming sword. As his companions Aragorn and Boromir tried to rush to his aid, Gandalf made a desperate, powerful move: he struck the bridge with his staff, causing it to break directly beneath the Balrog, sending the creature plunging into the abyss. However, as the Balrog fell, its whip lashed out, catching Gandalf and dragging him over the edge as well. With a final cry of "Fly, you fools!" to his friends, Gandalf too vanished into the darkness below.

They are quiet, reserved, and prefer to keep most of their thoughts to themselves rather than speaking frequently or sharing everything they are considering.

quote: We meet again, at the turn of the tide. A great storm is coming, but the tide has turned.

It conveys a sense of readiness and a belief that despite the coming difficulties, the underlying trend has become more favorable, making them better prepared to face what lies ahead.

quote: He charged the ranks of the goblins of Mount Gram in the Battle of the Green Fields, and knocked their king Golfimbul's head clean off with a wooden club. It expresses an unwavering commitment to succeed, no matter how immense the cost or hardship.

quote:
Fare well we call to hearth and hall

We must away ere break of day

With foes ahead behind us dread
Beneath the sky shall be our bed
Until at last our toil be sped
Our journey done, our errand sped
We must away! We must away!
We ride before the break of day!

quote: It is the way of my people to use light words at such times and say less than they mean. We fear to say too much. It robs us of the right words when a jest is out of place.

They are careful not to say too much because they worry that being overly serious or emotional would make it harder for them to use humor or lightheartedness when it's actually appropriate. Essentially, they prefer to keep things understated and a bit detached to maintain their ability to use jokes and levity.

quote: The burned hand teaches best. After that, advice about fire goes to the heart.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: The burned hand teaches best. After that, advice about fire goes to the heart.

After such a personal and immediate consequence, advice and warnings that might have been dismissed before are finally understood and taken seriously.

quote: Help means ruin and saving means slaying.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Help means ruin and saving means slaying.

In this view, the very act of providing assistance can, paradoxically, destroy a person's independence or ability to stand strong on their own.

quote: The others cast themselves down upon the fragrant grass, but Frodo stood awhile still lost in wonder. It seemed to him that he had stepped through a high window that looked on a vanished world. A light was upon it for which his language had no name. All that he saw was shapely, but the shapes seemed at once clear cut, as if they had been first conceived and drawn at the uncovering of his eyes, and ancient as if they had endured for ever. He saw no colour but those he knew, gold and white and blue and green, but they were fresh and poignant, as if he had at that moment first perceived them and made for them names new and wonderful. In winter here no heart could mourn for summer or for spring. No blemish or sickness or deformity could be seen in anything that grew upon the earth. On the land of Lórien, there was no stain.

quote: Well, I am going back into the open air, to see what the wind and sky are doing!

quote: Such is of the course of deeds that move the wheels of the world: small hands do them because they must, while the eyes of the great are elsewhere.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Such is of the course of deeds that move the wheels of the world: small hands do them because they must, while the eyes of the great are elsewhere.

These individuals perform essential tasks, not always by choice, but because they are necessary. Meanwhile, those in positions of power or with great influence are frequently oblivious to or uninterested in these crucial efforts, focusing their attention on other matters.

quote: Already he was a very different hobbit from the one that had run out without a pocket-handkerchief from Bag-End long ago. He had not had a pocket-handkerchief for ages.

Now, after a long time away and many experiences, he is much more seasoned and no longer expects or needs such everyday comforts, showing how much he has adapted and grown.

quote:
Are you in pain, Frodo?' said Gandalf quietly as he rode by Frodo's side.

'Well, yes I am,' said Frodo. 'It is my shoulder. The wound aches, and the memory of darkness is heavy on me. It was a year ago today.'

'Alas! there are some wounds that cannot be wholly cured,' said Gandalf.

'I fear it may be so with mine,' said Frodo. 'There is no real going back. Though I may come to the Shire, it will not seem the same; for I shall not be the same. I am wounded with knife, sting, and tooth, and a long burden. Where shall I find rest?'

Gandalf did not answer.

He believes even returning home won't be the same because he himself is no longer the same person. Burdened by his many injuries and trials, Frodo asks where he can find rest, but Gandalf remains silent.
