− Tiel pensas ankaŭ mi, − diris Gandalfo, − kaj tiel pensas ĉiuj, kiuj travivas tiajn epokojn. Sed tion ne ili decidas. Ni rajtas decidi nur tion, kion fari dum la tempo allasita al ni.
summary: Frodo laments that the difficult events are happening during his lifetime. Gandalf agrees, stating that everyone who lives through such challenging times feels the same way. However, Gandalf points out that people don't get to choose *when* these hardships occur. Instead, our only power is to decide what we will do with the time we are given.

quote: For I was talking aloud to myself. A habit of the old: they choose the wisest person present to speak to;
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: For I was talking aloud to myself. A habit of the old: they choose the wisest person present to speak to;
summary: This quote explains that the speaker was talking aloud to themselves, which they note is a common habit among older people. The reason for this, they suggest, is that older individuals tend to talk to themselves because they consider themselves the most knowledgeable or wisest person available to have a conversation with.

quote: Anar calúva tielyanna
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Anar calúva tielyanna
summary: The quote "Anar calúva tielyanna" is from the Elvish language of Quenya, and it directly translates to **"The Sun will shine upon your path."** In simpler terms, it's a message of hope and assurance. It suggests that even when you face difficulties or darkness in your life's journey, light, guidance, and good fortune will eventually illuminate your way forward, helping you to see clearly and find your path. It's an encouraging phrase that promises a brighter future.

quote: He led the way in under the huge branches of the trees. Old beyond guessing, they seemed. Great trailing beards of lichen hung from them, blowing and swaying in the breeze. Out of the shadows, the hobbits peeped, gazing back down the slope: little furtive figures that in the dim light looked like elf-children in the deeps of time peering out of the Wild Wood in wonder at their first Dawn.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: He led the way in under the huge branches of the trees. Old beyond guessing, they seemed. Great trailing beards of lichen hung from them, blowing and swaying in the breeze. Out of the shadows, the hobbits peeped, gazing back down the slope: little furtive figures that in the dim light looked like elf-children in the deeps of time peering out of the Wild Wood in wonder at their first Dawn.
summary: Someone led the way into a forest with incredibly old trees, from which long, beard-like moss hung and swayed in the breeze. From the shadows, the hobbits quietly peered back down the hill. In the dim light, their small, secretive figures looked like ancient elf-children emerging from a wild wood, gazing with wide-eyed wonder as if seeing the world for the very first time.

quote: Men in Númenor are half-Elves (said Erendis), especially the high men; they are neither the one nor the other. The long life that they were granted deceives them, and they dally in the world, children in mind, until age finds them – and then many only forsake play out of doors for play in their houses. They turn their play into great matters and great matters into play. They would be craftsmen and loremasters and heroes all at once; and women to them are but fires on the hearth – for others to tend, until they are tired of play in the evening. All things were made for their service: hills are for quarries, river to furnish water or to turn wheels, trees for boards, women for their body’s need, or if fair to adorn their table and hearth; and children to be teased when nothing else is to do – but they would as soon play with their hounds’ whelps. To all they are gracious and kind, merry as larks in the morning (if the sun shines); for they are never wrathful if they can avoid it. Men should be gay, they hold, generous as the rich, giving away what they do not need. Anger they show only when they become aware, suddenly, that there are other wills in the world beside their own. Then they will be as ruthless as the seawind if anything dare to withstand them. Thus it is, Ancalimë, and we cannot alter it. For men fashioned Númenor: men, those heroes of old that they sing of – of their women we hear less, save that they wept when their men were slain. Númenor was to be a rest after war. But if they weary of rest and the plays of peace, soon they will go back to their great play, manslaying and war. Thus it is; and we are set here among them. But we need not assent. If we love Númenor also, let us enjoy it before they ruin it. We also are daughters of the great, and we have wills and courage of our own. Therefore do not bend, Ancalimë. Once bend a little, and they will bend you further until you are bowed down. Sink your roots into the rock, and face the wind, though it blow away all your leaves.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Men in Númenor are half-Elves (said Erendis), especially the high men; they are neither the one nor the other. The long life that they were granted deceives them, and they dally in the world, children in mind, until age finds them – and then many only forsake play out of doors for play in their houses. They turn their play into great matters and great matters into play. They would be craftsmen and loremasters and heroes all at once; and women to them are but fires on the hearth – for others to tend, until they are tired of play in the evening. All things were made for their service: hills are for quarries, river to furnish water or to turn wheels, trees for boards, women for their body’s need, or if fair to adorn their table and hearth; and children to be teased when nothing else is to do – but they would as soon play with their hounds’ whelps. To all they are gracious and kind, merry as larks in the morning (if the sun shines); for they are never wrathful if they can avoid it. Men should be gay, they hold, generous as the rich, giving away what they do not need. Anger they show only when they become aware, suddenly, that there are other wills in the world beside their own. Then they will be as ruthless as the seawind if anything dare to withstand them. Thus it is, Ancalimë, and we cannot alter it. For men fashioned Númenor: men, those heroes of old that they sing of – of their women we hear less, save that they wept when their men were slain. Númenor was to be a rest after war. But if they weary of rest and the plays of peace, soon they will go back to their great play, manslaying and war. Thus it is; and we are set here among them. But we need not assent. If we love Númenor also, let us enjoy it before they ruin it. We also are daughters of the great, and we have wills and courage of our own. Therefore do not bend, Ancalimë. Once bend a little, and they will bend you further until you are bowed down. Sink your roots into the rock, and face the wind, though it blow away all your leaves.
summary: Erendis describes Númenorean men as long-lived but emotionally immature, like children who never truly grow up. They treat all of life, even serious matters, as a form of play, seeing themselves as multi-talented heroes while viewing nature, women, and children merely as tools for their convenience or amusement. Though outwardly charming, generous, and merry, they become ruthlessly unyielding when their will is challenged. Erendis warns that this self-centered immaturity, combined with their eventual boredom with peace, will inevitably lead them back to war and destruction. Therefore, she urges Ancalimë and other women not to yield to these men, but to stand firm with their own will and courage, even if it means facing hardship, to avoid being completely dominated.

quote: Literature shrivels in a universal language, and an uprooted language rots before it dies. And it should be possible to lift the eyes above the cant of the ‘language of Shakespeare’... sufficiently to realise the magnitude of the loss to humanity that the world-dominance of any one language now spoken would entail: no language has ever possessed but a small fraction of the varied excellences of human speech, and each language represents a different vision of life ...
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Literature shrivels in a universal language, and an uprooted language rots before it dies. And it should be possible to lift the eyes above the cant of the ‘language of Shakespeare’... sufficiently to realise the magnitude of the loss to humanity that the world-dominance of any one language now spoken would entail: no language has ever possessed but a small fraction of the varied excellences of human speech, and each language represents a different vision of life ...
summary: The author argues that forcing a universal language harms literature and causes other languages to decay and eventually die. We should look beyond the perceived superiority of any single language, like English, and understand the immense loss it would be for humanity if one language dominated the world. This is because no single language possesses the full range of human expression, and each language offers a unique and valuable way of understanding life.

quote: So time drew on to the War of the Ring, and the sons of Denethor grew to manhood. Boromir, five years the elder, beloved by his father, was like him in face and pride, but in little else. Rather he was a man after the sort of King Eärnur of old, taking no wife and delighting chiefly in arms; fearless and strong, but caring little for lore, save the tales of old battles. Faramir the younger was like him in looks but otherwise in mind. He read the hearts of men as shrewdly as his father, but what he read moved him sooner to pity than to scorn. He was gentle in bearing, and a lover of lore and of music, and therefore by many in those days his courage was judged less than his brother’s. But it was not so, except that he did not seek glory in danger without a purpose. He welcomed Gandalf at such times as he came to the City, and he learned what he could from his wisdom; and in this as in many other matters he displeased his father. ‘Yet between the brothers there was great love, and had been since childhood, when Boromir was the helper and protector of Faramir. No jealousy or rivalry had arisen between them since, for their father’s favour or for the praise of men. It did not seem possible to Faramir that anyone in Gondor could rival Boromir, heir of Denethor, Captain of the White Tower; and of like mind was Boromir. Yet it proved otherwise at the test. But of all that befell these three in the War of the Ring much is said elsewhere.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: So time drew on to the War of the Ring, and the sons of Denethor grew to manhood. Boromir, five years the elder, beloved by his father, was like him in face and pride, but in little else. Rather he was a man after the sort of King Eärnur of old, taking no wife and delighting chiefly in arms; fearless and strong, but caring little for lore, save the tales of old battles. Faramir the younger was like him in looks but otherwise in mind. He read the hearts of men as shrewdly as his father, but what he read moved him sooner to pity than to scorn. He was gentle in bearing, and a lover of lore and of music, and therefore by many in those days his courage was judged less than his brother’s. But it was not so, except that he did not seek glory in danger without a purpose. He welcomed Gandalf at such times as he came to the City, and he learned what he could from his wisdom; and in this as in many other matters he displeased his father. ‘Yet between the brothers there was great love, and had been since childhood, when Boromir was the helper and protector of Faramir. No jealousy or rivalry had arisen between them since, for their father’s favour or for the praise of men. It did not seem possible to Faramir that anyone in Gondor could rival Boromir, heir of Denethor, Captain of the White Tower; and of like mind was Boromir. Yet it proved otherwise at the test. But of all that befell these three in the War of the Ring much is said elsewhere.
summary: As the War of the Ring approached, Denethor's two sons, Boromir and Faramir, grew to manhood, though they were very different. Boromir, the elder, was his father's favorite: proud, fearless, and a mighty warrior who cared little for learning, except for battle tales. Faramir, the younger, looked similar but was gentle and compassionate, loving books and music. He was wise and welcomed Gandalf's counsel, which displeased his father. Many underestimated Faramir's courage because of his gentle nature, but he was truly brave, just not reckless in seeking glory. Despite their contrasting personalities and their father's clear favoritism, the brothers shared a deep love and no jealousy. Both believed Boromir was unmatched in Gondor, though things would later change.

quote: A few melancholy birds were pipping and wailing, until the round red sun sank slowly into the western shadows; then an empty silence fell
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: A few melancholy birds were pipping and wailing, until the round red sun sank slowly into the western shadows; then an empty silence fell
summary: The quote describes a quiet evening scene where a few sad-sounding birds were making soft, mournful calls. They continued their sounds until the sun slowly set and disappeared into the western horizon. Once the sun was completely gone, all the bird noises stopped, and a deep, complete silence fell over everything.

quote: Or more important, I an a Christian (which can be deduced from my stories), and in fact a Roman Catholic. The latter "fact" perhaps cannot be deduced; though one critic (by letter) asserted that the invocations of Elbereth, and the character of Galadriel as directly described (or through the words of Gimli and Sam) were clearly related to Catholic devotion to Mary. Another saw in waybread (lembras)=vaticum and the reference to its feeding the will (vol. III, p. 213) and being more potent when fasting, a derivation from the Eucharist. (letter 213)
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Or more important, I an a Christian (which can be deduced from my stories), and in fact a Roman Catholic. The latter "fact" perhaps cannot be deduced; though one critic (by letter) asserted that the invocations of Elbereth, and the character of Galadriel as directly described (or through the words of Gimli and Sam) were clearly related to Catholic devotion to Mary. Another saw in waybread (lembras)=vaticum and the reference to its feeding the will (vol. III, p. 213) and being more potent when fasting, a derivation from the Eucharist. (letter 213)
summary: In this quote, Tolkien confirms that he is a Roman Catholic, though he notes that this might not be immediately obvious from his stories. However, he points out that some critics have indeed found Catholic connections in his work. For example, one critic believed that the characters of Elbereth and Galadriel, particularly their invocations, resembled Catholic devotion to the Virgin Mary. Another critic saw a parallel between "waybread" (lembas) and the Eucharist, especially considering how it strengthens the will, particularly when fasting.

quote: The blind was down; but outside the moon rose up out of the sea, and laid the silver path across the waters that is the way to places at the edge of the world and beyond, for those that can walk on it.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: The blind was down; but outside the moon rose up out of the sea, and laid the silver path across the waters that is the way to places at the edge of the world and beyond, for those that can walk on it.
summary: The quote contrasts a feeling of being shut in or limited ("the blind was down") with the vast, inviting possibilities of the outside world. Outside, the moon creates a beautiful, shimmering path across the sea. This isn't just a pretty sight; it's a symbolic gateway to incredibly distant and unknown places, even beyond the edge of the world. However, this extraordinary journey is only accessible to those who possess the unique ability, courage, or vision to embark upon it.

quote: The Evangelium has not abrogated legends; it has hallowed them, especially the 'happy ending'. The Christian has still to work, with mind as well as body, to suffer, hope, and die; but he may now perceive that all his bents and faculties have a purpose, which can be redeemed. So great is the bounty with which he has been treated that he may now, perhaps, fairly dare to guess that in Fantasy he may actually assist in the effoliation and multiple enrichment of creation.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: The Evangelium has not abrogated legends; it has hallowed them, especially the 'happy ending'. The Christian has still to work, with mind as well as body, to suffer, hope, and die; but he may now perceive that all his bents and faculties have a purpose, which can be redeemed. So great is the bounty with which he has been treated that he may now, perhaps, fairly dare to guess that in Fantasy he may actually assist in the effoliation and multiple enrichment of creation.
summary: This quote suggests that Christianity doesn't reject old stories, legends, or even the idea of a "happy ending"; instead, it makes them sacred. While Christians still face life's struggles, they can now understand that all their natural talents and inclinations have a deeper purpose that can be made good. Because of the immense blessings they've received, they might even believe that their imagination, particularly through fantasy, can actively help creation become richer, more diverse, and more beautiful.

quote: Upon the further side, some way within the valley's arms, high on a rocky seat upon the black knees of the Ephel Dúath, stood the walls and tower of Minas Morgul. All was dark about it, earth and sky, but it was lit with light. Not the imprisoned moonlight welling through the marble walls of Minas Ithil long ago, Tower of the Moon, fair and radiant in the hollow of the hills. Paler indeed than the moon ailing in some slow eclipse was the light of it now, wavering and blowing like a noisome exhalation of decay, a corpse-light, a light that illuminated nothing.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Upon the further side, some way within the valley's arms, high on a rocky seat upon the black knees of the Ephel Dúath, stood the walls and tower of Minas Morgul. All was dark about it, earth and sky, but it was lit with light. Not the imprisoned moonlight welling through the marble walls of Minas Ithil long ago, Tower of the Moon, fair and radiant in the hollow of the hills. Paler indeed than the moon ailing in some slow eclipse was the light of it now, wavering and blowing like a noisome exhalation of decay, a corpse-light, a light that illuminated nothing.
summary: Minas Morgul is a fortress located high up in a dark valley, nestled among the black mountains of Ephel Dúath. Despite the darkness of its surroundings, the tower itself glows with a peculiar light. This is not the beautiful, radiant glow it once had as Minas Ithil, the Tower of the Moon. Instead, its light is sickly and pale, weaker than a dying moon, and it wavers like a foul, decaying breath. It's described as a "corpse-light" that illuminates nothing, emphasizing its eerie, morbid, and evil nature.

quote: It was dark and dim all day. From the sunless dawn until evening the heavy shadow had deepened, and all hearts in the City were oppressed. Far above a great cloud streamed slowly westward from the Black Land, devouring light, borne upon a wind of war; but below the air was still and breathless, as if all the Vale of Anduin waited for the onset of a ruinous storm.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: It was dark and dim all day. From the sunless dawn until evening the heavy shadow had deepened, and all hearts in the City were oppressed. Far above a great cloud streamed slowly westward from the Black Land, devouring light, borne upon a wind of war; but below the air was still and breathless, as if all the Vale of Anduin waited for the onset of a ruinous storm.
summary: The day was intensely dark from sunless dawn until evening, and this oppressive gloom weighed heavily on everyone in the City. High above, a massive cloud, carried by a "wind of war," slowly drifted from the ominous "Black Land," actively blotting out the light. Yet, down on the ground, the air was eerily still and silent, as if the entire region was holding its breath, anticipating the imminent arrival of a devastating storm.

quote: Mourn not overmuch! Mighty was the fallen, meet was his ending. When his mound is raised, women then shall weep. War now calls us!
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Mourn not overmuch! Mighty was the fallen, meet was his ending. When his mound is raised, women then shall weep. War now calls us!
summary: This quote advises against excessive immediate grief. It acknowledges that the person who died was mighty and that their death was a fitting end for such an important individual. It suggests that there will be a time for proper mourning and tears once the fallen warrior is buried and honored. However, the immediate priority is to answer the urgent call of war.

quote: If simple folk are free from care and fear, simple they will be, and we must be secret to keep them so.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: If simple folk are free from care and fear, simple they will be, and we must be secret to keep them so.
summary: This quote suggests that if ordinary people are kept comfortable and free from worries or fears, they will remain uncomplicated and easy to manage. To ensure this state continues, those in power believe they must work in secret, hiding their actions, to prevent the common folk from becoming more complex or questioning.

quote: I am very fond indeed of it, and of all the dear old Shire; but I think I need a holiday.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: I am very fond indeed of it, and of all the dear old Shire; but I think I need a holiday.
summary: The speaker expresses a deep and genuine love for their home, the old Shire, and everything within it. However, despite this strong affection, they feel a personal need for a change of pace and a vacation.

quote: For a man may love war, and yet dread many things.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: For a man may love war, and yet dread many things.
summary: This quote suggests that someone can be drawn to war, perhaps finding purpose, glory, or even a certain excitement in it. However, despite this attraction or commitment, they can simultaneously experience profound fears. These fears might not just be about personal injury or death, but also about the consequences of war, the suffering it inflicts, the potential for defeat, or the loss of loved ones and comrades. It highlights the complex and often contradictory emotions a person can hold when facing conflict.

quote:
Well here we are, just the four of us that started out together,' said Merry. 'We have left all the rest behind, one after another. It seems almost like a dream that has slowly faded.'
'Not to me,' said Frodo. 'To me it feels more like falling asleep again.
prompt_template:
Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Well here we are, just the four of us that started out together,' said Merry. 'We have left all the rest behind, one after another. It seems almost like a dream that has slowly faded.'
'Not to me,' said Frodo. 'To me it feels more like falling asleep again.
summary: Merry observes that only four of them remain from their original group, as their other companions have gradually departed. He feels that their past journey now seems like a dream that is slowly losing its clarity and vividness. However, Frodo disagrees; for him, the experience feels more like falling asleep again, suggesting a sense of peaceful conclusion or a return to a much-needed state of rest after a long and difficult ordeal.

quote:
Too often have I heard of duty [...]. May I not now spend my life as I will?'
‘Few may do so with honour.'
‘Shall I always be left behind when the Riders depart, to mind the house while they win renown, and find food and beds when they return?’
‘A time may come soon,’ said he, ‘when none will return. Then there will be need of valour without renown, for none shall remember the deeds that are done in the last defence of your homes. Yet the deeds will not be less valiant because they are unpraised.’ […]
‘I can ride and wield blade, and I do not fear either pain or death.’
‘What do you fear, lady?’ he asked.
‘A cage,’ she said. ‘To stay behind bars, until use and old age accept them, and all chance of doing great deeds is gone beyond recall or desire.
prompt_template:
Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Too often have I heard of duty [...]. May I not now spend my life as I will?'
‘Few may do so with honour.'
‘Shall I always be left behind when the Riders depart, to mind the house while they win renown, and find food and beds when they return?’
‘A time may come soon,’ said he, ‘when none will return. Then there will be need of valour without renown, for none shall remember the deeds that are done in the last defence of your homes. Yet the deeds will not be less valiant because they are unpraised.’ […]
‘I can ride and wield blade, and I do not fear either pain or death.’
‘What do you fear, lady?’ he asked.
‘A cage,’ she said. ‘To stay behind bars, until use and old age accept them, and all chance of doing great deeds is gone beyond recall or desire.
summary: A person expresses deep frustration with constantly hearing about duty, wishing instead to live their life freely and participate in great deeds, rather than being left behind. Another character cautions that true honor doesn't always allow for personal desires, warning that a time may come when courage will be needed without any praise or recognition. The first person, stating their own bravery and skill in battle, then reveals their greatest fear: being confined and missing the chance to achieve anything significant before old age takes away all possibility.

quote: The sky was clear and the stars were growing bright. ‘It’s going to be a fine night,’ he said aloud. ‘That’s good for a beginning. I feel like walking.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: The sky was clear and the stars were growing bright. ‘It’s going to be a fine night,’ he said aloud. ‘That’s good for a beginning. I feel like walking.
summary: The quote describes a beautiful, clear evening where the stars are starting to shine. The speaker is pleased, noting that it will be a "fine night" and that this good beginning makes him feel like taking a walk. Essentially, the pleasant weather inspires him to go for a stroll.

quote: They
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: They
summary: The "quote," consisting solely of the word "They," is a pronoun that refers to multiple people or things. However, without any surrounding context, this single word conveys no specific message, idea, or complete thought. Its meaning is entirely dependent on the rest of the sentence or conversation it was taken from, so on its own, it offers no discernible information about who "they" are or what is being said about them.

quote: Art moves them and they don't know what they've been moved by and they get quite drunk on it.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Art moves them and they don't know what they've been moved by and they get quite drunk on it.
summary: This quote means that art has a profound emotional effect on people, stirring strong feelings within them. However, those experiencing the art don't always understand or can't pinpoint the exact reason *why* they feel so deeply moved. This powerful emotional response is so overwhelming and captivating that it's compared to being drunk, making them feel exhilarated and fully absorbed in the experience without needing to analyze its source.

quote: But if a waking writer tells you that his tale is only a thing imagined in his sleep, he cheats deliberately the primal desire at the heart of Faërie: the realization, independent of the conceiving mind, of imagined wonder.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: But if a waking writer tells you that his tale is only a thing imagined in his sleep, he cheats deliberately the primal desire at the heart of Faërie: the realization, independent of the conceiving mind, of imagined wonder.
summary: This quote suggests that when a fantasy writer dismisses their own magical stories as just something they made up or dreamed, they are betraying a deep human need. This need, which is central to why we enjoy fantasy, is the desire for the imagined wonders to feel truly real and to exist independently, as if they have a life of their own beyond just the author's mind. We want to believe, even momentarily, that the fantastic elements could actually be true.

quote: But if you would know, I am turning aside soon. I am going to have a long talk with Bombadil: such a talk as I have not had in all my time. He is a moss-gatherer, and I have been a stone doomed to rolling. But my rolling days are ending, and now we shall have much to say to one another.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: But if you would know, I am turning aside soon. I am going to have a long talk with Bombadil: such a talk as I have not had in all my time. He is a moss-gatherer, and I have been a stone doomed to rolling. But my rolling days are ending, and now we shall have much to say to one another.
summary: The speaker is about to change course and have a long, significant conversation with Bombadil, a type of talk they haven't experienced before. The speaker explains that Bombadil is someone who stays put and is rooted, like a "moss-gatherer," while the speaker has always been active and constantly on the move, like a "stone doomed to rolling." However, the speaker's days of constant activity are ending, which means they can finally connect deeply and share much with Bombadil.

quote: Death was ever present, because the Númenóreans still, as they had in their old kingdom, and so lost it, hungered after endless life unchanging. Kings made tombs more splendid than houses of the living, and counted old names in the rolls of their descent dearer than the names of sons. Childless lords sat in aged halls musing on heraldry; in secret chambers withered men compounded strong elixirs, or in high cold towers asked questions of the stars.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Death was ever present, because the Númenóreans still, as they had in their old kingdom, and so lost it, hungered after endless life unchanging. Kings made tombs more splendid than houses of the living, and counted old names in the rolls of their descent dearer than the names of sons. Childless lords sat in aged halls musing on heraldry; in secret chambers withered men compounded strong elixirs, or in high cold towers asked questions of the stars.
summary: The Númenóreans were deeply afraid of death and desperately longed for eternal life, which ironically made them constantly aware of their mortality. This obsession led them to prioritize the past and the dead over the living and the future. They built grand tombs that outshone homes for the living, valuing ancestral names more than their own children. Some old, childless nobles dwelled on their family histories, while others, in their desperation, tried to find immortality through secret potions or by seeking answers from the stars.

quote: In many ways,' answered the wizard. 'It is far more powerful than I ever dared to think at first, so powerful that in the end it would utterly overcome anyone of mortal race who possessed it. It would possess him.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: In many ways,' answered the wizard. 'It is far more powerful than I ever dared to think at first, so powerful that in the end it would utterly overcome anyone of mortal race who possessed it. It would possess him.
summary: The wizard is explaining that whatever "it" refers to is astonishingly powerful, far more potent than he initially believed. He warns that this immense power isn't something a mortal can simply wield; instead, it's so overwhelming that it would eventually dominate and completely control anyone who possessed it, turning the wielder into the one being possessed.

quote: A fair vision had welcomed him in this land of disease.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: A fair vision had welcomed him in this land of disease.
summary: This quote means that even though the person was in a very difficult and troubled place, described as a "land of disease" (implying sickness, suffering, or despair), they encountered something beautiful and positive. This "fair vision" acted as a comforting and welcoming presence, offering a moment of relief or hope in an otherwise bleak environment.

quote: He did not falter, as long as there was a path that led toward his goal.

quote:
Tell me, Legolas, why did I come on this Quest? Little did I know where the chief peril lay! Truly Elrond spoke, saying that we could not foresee what we might meet upon our road. Torment in the dark was the danger that O feared, and it did not hold me back. But I would not have come, had I known the danger of light and joy. Now I have taken my worst wound in this parting, even if I were to go this night straight to the Dark Lord. Alas for Gimli son of Gloin!

Nay said Legolas. Alas for us all! And for all that walk the world in these after-days, For such is the way of it: to find and lose, as it seems to those whose boat is on the running stream. But I count you blessed, Gimli son of Gloin: for your loss you suffer of your own free will, and you might have chosen otherwise. But you have not forsaken your companions, and the least reward that you shall have is that the memory of Lothlorien shall remain ever clear and unstained in your heart, and shall neither fade nor grow stale.

Maybe, said Gimli; and I thank you for your words. True words doubtless; yet all such comfort is cold. Memory is not what the heart desires. That is only a mirror, be it clear as Kheled-zaram. Or so says the heart of Gimli.

Truly Elrond spoke, saying that we could not foresee what we might meet upon our road. Torment in the dark was the danger that O feared, and it did not hold me back. But I would not have come, had I known the danger of light and joy. Now I have taken my worst wound in this parting, even if I were to go this night straight to the Dark Lord. Alas for Gimli son of Gloin!

Nay said Legolas. Alas for us all! And for all that walk the world in these after-days, For such is the way of it: to find and lose, as it seems to those whose boat is on the running stream. But I count you blessed, Gimli son of Gloin: for your loss you suffer of your own free will, and you might have chosen otherwise. But you have not forsaken your companions, and the least reward that you shall have is that the memory of Lothlorien shall remain ever clear and unstained in your heart, and shall neither fade nor grow stale.

Maybe, said Gimli; and I thank you for your words. True words doubtless; yet all such comfort is cold. Memory is not what the heart desires. That is only a mirror, be it clear as Kheled-zaram. Or so says the heart of Gimli.
summary: Gimli expresses profound sorrow and regret, realizing that the deepest wound he has received on his journey isn't from the dangers he feared, but from the unexpected joy and beauty he experienced in Lothlórien, and the pain of having to leave it. He feels this parting is his worst injury and wishes he had never known such happiness if it meant enduring such a bitter loss. Legolas attempts to console him, explaining that finding and losing are inherent to life's journey. He considers Gimli blessed because he chose this suffering willingly by remaining loyal to his companions, assuring him that the beautiful memories of Lothlórien will remain untainted in his heart. However, Gimli responds that while Legolas's words may be true, they offer cold comfort, as memory, no matter how clear, is merely a reflection and not the presence his heart truly desires.

quote: There, peeping among the cloud-wrack above a dark tor high up in the mountains, Sam saw a white star twinkle for a while. quote: Behind that, there was something else at work, beyond any design of the ring maker. I can put it no plainer than by saying that Bilbo was meant to find the ring, and not by its maker. In which case you also were meant to have it. And that may be an encouraging thought.

quote: Faithfulness in Christian marriage entails that: great mortification. For a Christian man there is no escape. Marriage may help to sanctify and direct to its proper object his sexual desires; its grace may help him in the struggle; but the struggle remains. It will not satisfy him–as hunger may be kept off by regular meals. It will offer as many difficulties to the purity proper to that state, as it provides easements. No man, however truly he loved his betrothed and bride as a young man, has lived faithful to her as a wife in mind and body without deliberate conscious exercise of the will, without self-denial.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Faithfulness in Christian marriage entails that: great mortification. For a Christian man there is no escape. It will not satisfy him–as hunger may be kept off by regular meals. It will offer as many difficulties to the purity proper to that state, as it provides easements. No man, however truly he loved his betrothed and bride as a young man, has lived faithful to her as a wife in mind and body without deliberate conscious exercise of the will, without self-denial.
summary: This quote explains that being faithful in a Christian marriage demands significant self-sacrifice and a constant struggle, especially for men regarding their sexual desires. While marriage can help direct these desires and offer grace, it doesn't eliminate the struggle or provide automatic satisfaction like food satisfies hunger. In fact, it can present as many challenges to purity as it eases. Ultimately, the quote argues that true faithfulness—both in mind and body—is never automatic, even for deeply loving men; it always requires deliberate, conscious willpower and continuous self-denial throughout the marriage.

quote: Much evil must befall a country before it wholly forgets the Elves, if once they dwelt there.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Much evil must befall a country before it wholly forgets the Elves, if once they dwelt there.

"The Elves" here symbolize the pure, beautiful, or magical qualities that once characterized the land and its people. Therefore, for a nation to entirely forget such a vital and positive part of its past implies it has truly fallen into a very dark and corrupted state.

quote:
I am in too great doubt to rule. To prepare or to let be? To prepare for war, which is yet only guessed: train craftsmen and tillers in the midst of peace for bloodspilling and battle: put iron in the hands of greedy captains who will love only conquest, and count the slain as their glory? Will they say to Eru: "At least your enemies were amongst them?" Or to fold hands, while friends die unjustly: let men live in blind peace, until the ravisher is at the gate? What then will they do: match naked hands against iron and die in vain, or flee leaving the cries of women behind them? Will they say to Eru: "At least I spilled no blood?"

-- Tar-Meneldur in Armenelos, Aldarion and Erendis: The Mariner's Wife
prompt_template:
Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: I am in too great doubt to rule. To prepare or to let be? To prepare for war, which is yet only guessed: train craftsmen and tillers in the midst of peace for bloodspilling and battle: put iron in the hands of greedy captains who will love only conquest, and count the slain as their glory? Will they say to Eru: "At least your enemies were amongst them?" Or to fold hands, while friends die unjustly: let men live in blind peace, until the ravisher is at the gate? What then will they do: match naked hands against iron and die in vain, or flee leaving the cries of women behind them? Will they say to Eru: "At least I spilled no blood?"

-- Tar-Meneldur in Armenelos, Aldarion and Erendis: The Mariner's Wife
summary: Tar-Meneldur is deeply conflicted and unsure how to rule. He faces a terrible dilemma: should he prepare for a potential war, which would mean training peaceful citizens to kill and risking the rise of power-hungry leaders who glorify conquest and death? He wonders if such bloodshed could ever be justified to their god. Or should he do nothing, letting his people live in peace until an enemy suddenly attacks, leaving them defenseless to be slaughtered or forced to flee in shame, abandoning their loved ones? He questions if inaction and avoiding bloodshed would be a valid excuse when so many suffer. He struggles with the heavy burden of choosing between two paths, both fraught with terrible consequences.

quote: Among the tales of sorrow and of ruin that came down to us from the darkness of those days there are yet some in which amid weeping there is joy and under the shadow of death light that endures.

quote:
Tears unnumbered ye shall shed; and the Valar will fence Valinor against you, and shut you out, so that not even the echo of your lamentation shall pass over the mountains. On the House of Fëanor the wrath of the Valar lieth from the West unto the uttermost East, and upon all that will follow them it shall be laid also. Their Oath shall drive them, and yet betray them, and ever snatch away the very treasures that they have sworn to pursue. To evil end shall all things turn that they begin well; and by treason of kin unto kin, and the fear of treason, shall this come to pass. The Dispossessed shall they be for ever.
Ye have spilled the blood of your kindred unrighteously and have stained the land of Aman. For blood ye shall render blood, and beyond Aman ye shall dwell in Death's shadow. For though Eru appointed to you to die not in Eä, and no sickness may assail you, yet slain ye may be, and slain ye shall be: by weapon and by torment and by grief; and your houseless spirits shall come then to Mandos. There long shall ye abide and yearn for your bodies, and find little pity though all whom ye have slain should entreat for you. And those that endure in Middle-earth and come not to Mandos shall grow weary of the world as with a great burden, and shall wane, and become as shadows of regret before the younger race that cometh after. The Valar have spoken.

To evil end shall all things turn that they begin well; and by treason of kin unto kin, and the fear of treason, shall this come to pass. The Dispossessed shall they be for ever.
Ye have spilled the blood of your kindred unrighteously and have stained the land of Aman. For blood ye shall render blood, and beyond Aman ye shall dwell in Death's shadow. For though Eru appointed to you to die not in Eä, and no sickness may assail you, yet slain ye may be, and slain ye shall be: by weapon and by torment and by grief; and your houseless spirits shall come then to Mandos. There long shall ye abide and yearn for your bodies, and find little pity though all whom ye have slain should entreat for you. And those that endure in Middle-earth and come not to Mandos shall grow weary of the world as with a great burden, and shall wane, and become as shadows of regret before the younger race that cometh after. The Valar have spoken.
summary: This quote, delivered by the Valar, is a dire curse upon the Noldor, particularly the House of Fëanor, for shedding the blood of their kin and defiling the blessed land of Aman. As punishment, they will be eternally shut out of Valinor, and the wrath of the Valar will follow them wherever they go. Their solemn oath, which drives them, will paradoxically betray them, ensuring they never truly possess the treasures they pursue. Everything they attempt, even with good intentions, will end in ruin, often due to betrayal among their own kin. They are condemned to be forever dispossessed. Furthermore, though they are immortal, they will face death by violence, torment, and grief, paying blood for blood, and their spirits will be trapped in Mandos with little hope of release, while those who remain in Middle-earth will slowly fade away into regretful shadows. This is the unyielding judgment of the Valar.

quote: Of those demons of power Ecthelion slew three, for the brightness of his sword cleft the iron of them and did hurt to their fire, and they writhed; yet of the leap of that axe Dramborleg that was swung by the hand of Tuor were they still more afraid, for it sang like the rush of eagle’s wings in the air and took death as it fell, and five of them went down before it.

quote: Words should not be used merely because they are 'old' or obsolete. The words chosen, however remote they may be from colloquial speech or ephemeral suggestions, must be words that remain in literary use, especially in the use of verse, among educated people. (To such Beowulf was addressed, into whatever hands it may since have fallen.) They must need no gloss. The fact that a word was still used by Chaucer, or by Shakespeare, or even later, gives it no claim, if it has in our time perished from literary use.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Words should not be used merely because they are 'old' or obsolete. The words chosen, however remote they may be from colloquial speech or ephemeral suggestions, must be words that remain in literary use, especially in the use of verse, among educated people. (To such Beowulf was addressed, into whatever hands it may since have fallen.) They must need no gloss. The fact that a word was still used by Chaucer, or by Shakespeare, or even later, gives it no claim, if it has in our time perished from literary use.
summary: When choosing words for writing, especially poetry, don't just pick them because they are old or obsolete. Instead, select words that are still actively used in literature by educated people, even if they aren't common in everyday conversation. These words should be clear enough that they don't require an explanation or a dictionary. It doesn't matter if famous writers like Chaucer or Shakespeare once used a word; if it's no longer found in modern literary usage, it shouldn't be used.

quote: Pity? It was Pity that stayed his hand. Pity, and Mercy: not to strike without need. And he has been well rewarded, Frodo. Be sure that he took so little hurt from the evil, and escaped in the end, because he began his ownership of the Ring so. With Pity.

quote: It's like in the great stories Mr. Frodo, the ones that really mattered. He declares he will swear an oath on "the Precious," which is his name for the powerful and corrupting One Ring. Frodo immediately reacts with strong anger and surprise, sternly asking how Gollum could dare to make such a vow. Frodo's intense reaction shows he understands the immense and dangerous significance of swearing on the Ring, urging Gollum to think carefully about the profound implications of his words.

quote: He floated by them, and slowly his boat departed, waning to a dark spot against the golden light; and then suddenly it vanished. Rauros roared on unchanging. He was never seen again in Minas Tirith, his home city, where he once stood proudly on the White Tower. However, in the years that followed, people in Gondor often told the tale that his elven-boat carried him safely over the roaring falls, through the city of Osgiliath, and past the river's many outlets, finally reaching the vast Great Sea at night under the stars.

quote:

By streams that never find the sea;
Over snow by winter sown,

Over grass and under stone,
And under mountains in the moon.
Roads go ever ever on
Under cloud and under star
Yet feet that wandering have gone
Turn at last to home afar.
Eyes that fire and sword have seen
And horror in the halls of stone
Look at last on meadows green
And trees and hills they long have known.

quote: In three days, as the King had said, Éomer of Rohan came riding to the City, and with him came an éored of the fairest knights of the Mark. And before he went to his rest he sent for Gimli the Dwarf, and he said to him: ‘Gimli Glóin’s son, have you your axe ready?’ ‘Nay, lord,’ said Gimli, ‘but I can speedily fetch it, if there be need.’ ‘You shall judge,’ said Éomer. ‘For there are certain rash words concerning the Lady in the Golden Wood that lie still between us. And now I have seen her with my eyes.’ ‘Well, lord,’ said Gimli, ‘and what say you now?’ ‘Alas!’ said Éomer. ‘I will not say that she is the fairest lady that lives.’ ‘Then I must go for my axe,’ said Gimli. ‘But first I will plead this excuse,’ said Éomer. ‘Had I seen her in other company, I would have said all that you could wish. But now I will put Queen Arwen Evenstar first, and I am ready to do battle on my own part with any who deny me. Shall I call for my sword?’ Then Gimli bowed low. ‘Nay, you are excused for my part, lord,’ he said. ‘You have chosen the Evening; but my love is given to the Morning. And my heart forebodes that soon it will pass away for ever.

Gimli, initially ready to fight to defend Galadriel's honor, accepted Éomer's change of heart, acknowledging their different preferences ("Morning" for Galadriel, "Evening" for Arwen) and expressing a sad premonition about his own beloved Lady.

summary: Frodo refuses to go to safety, believing he would be abandoning his friends to danger. However, Glorfindel corrects him, explaining that the opposite is true. He tells Frodo that the danger and the pursuit are actually focused on Frodo himself and the powerful item he carries (the One Ring). Glorfindel suggests that if Frodo were to leave, the danger would follow him, leaving his friends in peace and safety.

This transformation is compared to how humanity, when finally "redeemed" or perfected, will still be recognizable as human but will be fundamentally changed and improved from our current flawed state.

quote: Strange are the turns of fortune! Often does hatred hurt itself!

Second, it observes that holding onto hatred or acting out of it often ends up harming the person who feels that hatred more than their intended target, essentially backfiring on themselves.

quote: man that flies from his fear may find that he has only taken a short cut to meet it.

It suggests that avoiding a challenge is not a solution, but rather a deceptive path that quickly leads you right back to what you were trying to escape in the first place.

quote:
Thus Huan spake, who never before
had uttered words, and but twice more
did speak in elven tongue again;
'Lady beloved, whom all Men,
who Elfinesse, and whom all things
with fur and fell and feathered wings
should serve and love - arise! away!
Put on thy cloak! Before the day
comes over Nargothrond we fly
to Northern perils, thou and I.'
And ere he ceased he counsel wrought
for achievement of the thing they sought.
There Lúthien listened in amaze,
and softly on Huan did she gaze.
Her arms about his neck she cast -
In friendship that to death should last.

quote: Nienor ran on into the woods until she was spent, and then fell, and slept, and awoke; and it was a sunlit morning, and she rejoiced in light as it were a new thing, and all things else that she saw seemed new and strange, for she had no names for them.

quote: Why, to think of it, we’re in the same tale still! It’s going on. Don’t the great tales never end?’ ‘No, they never end as tales,’ said Frodo. ‘But the people in them come, and go when their part’s ended.

quote:
you do not go, because only your brother called for you, and to look on the Lord Aragorn, Elendil's heir, in his triumph would now bring you no joy. Or because I do not go, and you desire still to be near me. And maybe for both these reasons, and you yourself cannot choose between them. Éowyn, do you not love me, or will you not?'
'I wished to be loved by another,' she answered, 'But I desire no man's pity.'
'That I know,' he said. 'You desired to have the love of the Lord Aragorn. Because he was high and puissant, and you wished to have renown and glory and to be lifted far above the mean things that crawl on the earth. And as a great captain may to a young soldier he seemed to you admirable. For so he is, a lord among men, the greatest that now is. But when he gave you only understanding and pity, then you desired to have nothing, unless a brave death in battle. Look at me, Éowyn!'
And Éowyn looked at Faramir long and steadily; and Faramir said: 'Do not scorn pity that is the gift of a gentle heart, Éowyn! But I do not offer you my pity, For you are a lady high and valiant and have yourself won renown that shall not be forgotten; and you are a lady beautiful, I deem, beyond even the words of the Elven-tongue to tell. And I love you. Once I pitied your sorrow. But now, were you sorrowless, without fear or any lack, were you the blissful Queen of Gondor, still I would love you. Éowyn do you not love me?'
Then the heart of Éowyn changed, or else at last she understood it. And suddenly her winter passed, and the sun shone on her.
'I stand in Minas Anor, the Tower of the Sun,' she said; 'and behold! the Shadow has departed! I will be a sheildmaiden no longer, nor vie with the great Riders, nor take joy only in the songs of slaying. I will be a healer, and love all things that grow and are not barren.' And again she looked at Faramir. 'No longer do I desire to be a queen,' she said.
Then Faramir laughed merrily. 'That is well,' he said; 'for I am not a king. Yet I will wed with the White Lady of Rohan, if it be her will. And if she will, then let us cross the River and in happier days let us dwell in fair Ithilien and there make a garden. All things will grow with joy there, if the White Lady comes.

They then joyfully agree to marry and build a peaceful life together in Ithilien.

summary: The first speaker believes that a person who has become evil, just like their enemies, deserves death. quote: Deserves death! I daresay he does. Many that live deserve death. And some die that deserve life. Can you give that to them? Then be not too eager to deal out death in the name of justice, fearing for your own safety. Even the wise cannot see all ends.

summary: This quote advises caution when considering who deserves death. It acknowledges that some people might indeed seem to deserve it, and many bad people live on. However, it highlights the tragic truth that good people sometimes die, and unlike death, life cannot be given back. Therefore, the speaker warns against being too eager to cause someone's death, even if you believe it's for justice or your own safety, because no one, not even the wisest, can truly know all the future consequences of such an action.

quote: There long he sojourned alone and roamed about the shore or fared over the rocks at the ebb, marvelling at the pools and the great weeds, the dripping caverns and the strange sea-fowl that he saw and came to know; but the rise and fall of the water and the voice of the waves was ever to him the greatest wonder and ever did it seem a new and unimaginable thing.

quote: Tears unnumbered ye shall shed; and the Valar will fence Valinor against you, and shut you out, so that not even the echo of your lamentation shall pass over the mountains. quote: Both, also, desired to make things of their own that should be new and unthought of by others, and delighted in the praise of their skill. But Aulë remained faithful to Eru and submitted all that he did to his will; and he did not envy the works of others, but sought and gave counsel. Whereas Melkor spent hs spirit in envy and hate, until at last he could make nothing save in mockery of the thought of others, and all their works he destroyed if he could.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Both, also, desired to make things of their own that should be new and unthought of by others, and delighted in the praise of their skill. But Aulë remained faithful to Eru and submitted all that he did to his will; and he did not envy the works of others, but sought and gave counsel. Whereas Melkor spent hs spirit in envy and hate, until at last he could make nothing save in mockery of the thought of others, and all their works he destroyed if he could.
summary: Both Aulë and Melkor shared a desire to create new and original things, and they enjoyed receiving praise for their skills. However, they differed greatly in their approach. Aulë remained loyal to Eru (God), submitting his creations to His will, and he did not envy the works of others; instead, he offered and sought advice. In stark contrast, Melkor became consumed by envy and hate, eventually losing the ability to create anything truly original, only able to mock or twist the ideas of others, and he would destroy their works whenever he could.

quote:
Hush!" said Gandalf from the shadows at the back of the porch. "Evil things do not come into this valley; but all the same we should not name them. The Lord of the Ring is not Frodo, but the master of the Dark Tower of Mordor, whose power is again stretching out over the world. We are sitting in a fortress. Outside it is getting dark."
"Gandalf has been saying many cheerful things like that," said Pippin.

Pippin, with sarcasm, points out that Gandalf has been offering many similarly 'cheerful' remarks, underscoring the grim reality of their situation.

quote: Some who have read the book, or at any rate reviewed it, have found it boring, absurd, or contemptible; and I have no reason to complain, since I have similar opinions of their work, or of the kinds of writing that they evidently prefer.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Some who have read the book, or at any rate reviewed it, have found it boring, absurd, or contemptible; and I have no reason to complain, since I have similar opinions of their work, or of the kinds of writing that they evidently prefer.
summary: The author explains that some people who read or reviewed their book found it boring, silly, or worthless. However, the author isn't upset by this criticism. That's because the author feels the exact same way about the critics' own writing, or the kinds of books and writing styles that those critics prefer. In short, it's a mutual disagreement of taste.

quote: No great leap for a man, but a leap in the dark.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: No great leap for a man, but a leap in the dark.
summary: This quote suggests that a significant action, while it might seem like a big step from the outside, isn't necessarily a grand or easy advancement for the person taking it. Instead, it highlights that such an act is often a courageous move into the unknown, full of uncertainty and without a clear view of what the future holds. It emphasizes the risk and lack of clarity involved when someone embarks on something without knowing the outcome.

quote: Elrond was in his chair and the fire was on his face like summer-light upon the trees.

quote:

quote:
But at the last the gates of Utumno were broken and the halls unroofed, and Melkor took refuge in the uttermost pit. Then Tulkas stood forth as champion of the Valar and wrestled with him, and cast him upon his face; and he was bound with the chain Angainor that Aulë had wrought, and led captive; and the world had peace for a long age.
Nonetheless the Valar did not discover all the mighty vaults and caverns hidden with deceit far under the fortresses of Angband and Utumno. Many evil things still lingered there, and others were dispersed and fled into the dark and roamed in the waste places of the world, awaiting a more evil hour; and Sauron they did not find.
But when the Battle was ended and from the ruin of the North great clouds arose and hid the stars, the Valar drew Melkor back to Valinor, bound hand and foot, and blindfold; and he was brought to the Ring of Doom. There he lay upon his face before the feet of Manwë and sued for pardon; but his prayer was denied, and he was cast into prison in the fastness of Mandos, whence none can escape, neither Vala, nor Elf, nor mortal Man. Vast and strong are those halls, and they were built in the west of the land of Aman. There was Melkor doomed to abide for three ages long, before his cause should be tried anew, or he should plead again for pardon.

summary: After his fortress Utumno was destroyed, Melkor was defeated in battle by Tulkas, a champion of the Valar. However, the Valar did not discover all of Melkor's hidden evil places, and many wicked creatures, including Sauron, escaped or remained undiscovered. Melkor was then brought to Valinor, where he begged for forgiveness but was denied. As punishment, he was imprisoned in the inescapable halls of Mandos for three long ages.

quote: And she answered: ‘All your words are but to say: you are a woman, and your part is in the house. But when the men have died in battle and honour, you have leave to be burned in the house, for the men will need it no more. But I am of the House of Eorl and not a serving-woman. I can ride and wield blade, and I do not fear either pain or death.’ ‘What do you fear, lady?’ he asked. ‘A cage,’ she said. ‘To stay behind bars, until use and old age accept them, and all chance of doing great deeds is gone beyond recall or desire.

summary: This quote features a woman who strongly rejects the traditional idea that a woman's place is only in the home. When asked what she *does* fear, she reveals her deepest dread is being trapped or "caged"—living a confined, inactive life where she loses all chance to accomplish great deeds before old age sets in.

quote: As the world grows older there is loss and gain - let us not with modern insolence and blindness imagine it all gain; [...] but neither must we with neo-pagan obscurity of thought imagine it all loss.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: As the world grows older there is loss and gain - let us not with modern insolence and blindness imagine it all gain; [...] but neither must we with neo-pagan obscurity of thought imagine it all loss.
summary: As the world progresses and changes over time, it naturally experiences both positive developments and losses. We should not, with modern arrogance or a lack of insight, assume that everything is always improving or that there are no downsides to progress. However, we also must not, with a muddled or overly nostalgic way of thinking, believe that everything is only getting worse or that there are no benefits to modern times. Instead, we need to acknowledge that change always brings a mix of good and bad.

quote: Of course, it is likely enough, my friends,’ he said slowly, ‘likely enough that we are going to our doom: the last march of the Ents. But if we stayed at home and did nothing, doom would find us anyway, sooner or later.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Of course, it is likely enough, my friends,’ he said slowly, ‘likely enough that we are going to our doom: the last march of the Ents. But if we stayed at home and did nothing, doom would find us anyway, sooner or later.
summary: This quote suggests that the speaker and their companions are heading into a very dangerous situation where they will likely face destruction or "doom." However, the speaker argues that even if they were to stay home and do nothing, that same terrible fate would still eventually find them. Therefore, the message is that when faced with an inevitable bad outcome, taking a risky action is preferable to passively waiting for disaster to strike, as inaction offers no true escape.

quote: A darkness lies behind us; and we have turned our backs on it, and we do not desire to return thither even in thought. Westwards our hearts have been turned, and we believe that there we shall find Light.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: A darkness lies behind us; and we have turned our backs on it, and we do not desire to return thither even in thought. Westwards our hearts have been turned, and we believe that there we shall find Light.
summary: This quote suggests that we have a difficult or negative past, symbolized by "darkness," which we have consciously chosen to leave behind. We have no desire to ever return to that past, not even in our thoughts, because it was so unpleasant. Instead, our hopes and focus are now directed towards a new future or path, symbolized by "Westwards," where we strongly believe we will find solutions, enlightenment, and a much better, brighter existence.

quote:
Grey as a mouse,
Big as a house,
Nose like a snake,
I make the earth shake,
As I tramp through the grass;
Trees crack as I pass.
With horns in my mouth
I walk in the South,
Flapping big ears.
Beyond count of years
I stump round and round,
Never lie on the ground,
Not even to die.
Oliphaunt am I,
Biggest of all,
Huge, old, and tall.
If ever you'd met me
You wouldn't forget me.
If you never do,
You won't think I'm true;
But old Oliphaunt am I,
And I never lie.

Its enormous size causes the earth to shake and trees to crack as it walks, flapping its big ears in the South. This incredibly old creature never lies down, not even to die. The Oliphaunt claims to be the biggest, most immense, and oldest of all, asserting that anyone who met it would never forget it. Despite its unbelievable nature to those who haven't seen it, it insists it is true and does not lie.

quote: No one, I fancy, would discredit a story that the Archbishop of Canterbury slipped on a banana skin merely because he found that a similar comic mishap had been reported of many people, and especially of elderly gentlemen of dignity.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: No one, I fancy, would discredit a story that the Archbishop of Canterbury slipped on a banana skin merely because he found that a similar comic mishap had been reported of many people, and especially of elderly gentlemen of dignity.
summary: The quote suggests that most people wouldn't doubt a story about a very important and dignified person, like the Archbishop of Canterbury, having a silly accident, such as slipping on a banana peel. This holds true even if that particular type of funny mishap has been reported many times before, especially involving other respectable, older gentlemen. Essentially, the author argues that just because a humorous incident is common or a cliché doesn't mean it couldn't genuinely happen to a specific individual, no matter how dignified they are.

quote: But the delight of Earth, the wonder of it; the essential feeling as of the necessity for magic; that juggling with the golden moon and silver sun (such are they) that is man's universal pastime: these are the things to seek in the Kalevala. All the world to wheel about in, the Great Bear to play with and Orion and the Seven Stars all dangling magically in the branches of a silver birch enchanted by Väinämöinen; the splendid sorcerous scandalous villains of old to tell of when you have bathed in the 'Sauna' after binding the kine at close of day into pastures of little Suomi in the Marshes.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: But the delight of Earth, the wonder of it; the essential feeling as of the necessity for magic; that juggling with the golden moon and silver sun (such are they) that is man's universal pastime: these are the things to seek in the Kalevala. All the world to wheel about in, the Great Bear to play with and Orion and the Seven Stars all dangling magically in the branches of a silver birch enchanted by Väinämöinen; the splendid sorcerous scandalous villains of old to tell of when you have bathed in the 'Sauna' after binding the kine at close of day into pastures of little Suomi in the Marshes.
summary: This quote suggests that the Kalevala, a Finnish epic, is truly about the deep joy and wonder of the world, emphasizing humanity's inherent need for magic. It describes how people playfully interact with grand ideas like the sun and moon, and how the epic allows one to imagine exploring the entire world, with constellations like the Great Bear and Orion magically brought to life by figures such as Väinämöinen. Beyond this cosmic enchantment, the Kalevala also offers exciting stories of powerful, sometimes mischievous, ancient villains, all to be appreciated in the context of a simple, traditional Finnish life, like relaxing in a sauna after a day of work in the peaceful countryside.

quote:

Despite these unseen beginnings, it reaches immense heights, soaring far above trees and seemingly going "up, up." The paradox is that even though it's incredibly tall and seems to climb, it never actually grows or changes in size. The riddle is often interpreted as describing a mountain, which is rooted deep in the earth, towers over everything, but doesn't physically grow.

quote: Bilbo of course ought to have been on his guard; but Smaug had rather an overwhelming personality.

a drink she brewed of strength and dread

their harbour sought, and owls and cats
from hunting came with mournful cries,
night-stalking near with needle eyes.

quote: Fantasy is a higher form of Art, indeed the most nearly pure form, and so (when achieved) the most potent.

quote: There are no tidings,’ said the Warden, ‘save that the Lords have ridden to Morgul Vale; and men say that the new captain out of the North is their chief. A great lord is that, and a healer; and it is a thing passing strange to me that the healing hand should also wield the sword. It is not thus in Gondor now, though once it was so, if old tales be true. But for long years we healers have only sought to patch the rents made by the men of swords. Though we should still have enough to do without them: the world is full enough of hurts and mischances without wars to multiply them.’ ‘It needs but one foe to breed a war, not two, Master Warden,’ answered Éowyn. ‘And those who have not swords can still die upon them. Would you have the folk of Gondor gather you herbs only, when the Dark Lord gathers armies? And it is not always good to be healed in body. Nor is it always evil to die in battle, even in bitter pain.

She asks if Gondor should simply gather herbs while the Dark Lord gathers armies, and states that being healed isn't always good, nor is dying in battle always evil.

quote: The magic of Faërie is not an end in itself, its virtue is in its operations: among these are the satisfaction of certain primordial human desires. quote: Ecthelion must be similarly from Aegthelion. Latter element is a derivative of √stel 'remain firm'. The form with prefix 'sundóma', estel, was used in Q{uenya} and S{indarin} for 'hope' – sc. a temper of mind, steady, fixed in purpose, and difficult to dissuade and unlikely to fall into despair or abandon its purpose. prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Ecthelion must be similarly from Aegthelion. Latter element is a derivative of √stel 'remain firm'. The form with prefix 'sundóma', estel, was used in Q{uenya} and S{indarin} for 'hope' – sc. a temper of mind, steady, fixed in purpose, and difficult to dissuade and unlikely to fall into despair or abandon its purpose. The unprefixed stel- gave [? S verb] thel 'intend, mean, purpose, resolve, will'. So Q ? þelma 'a fixed idea,..., will.
summary: The name Ecthelion is linked to the root word "√stel," which means "to remain firm." This root is the basis for several words in Quenya and Sindarin. For instance, the word "estel" (with a prefix) means "hope," specifically a strong, unwavering kind of hope that reflects a steady mind, fixed purpose, and resistance to despair or being dissuaded. Without the prefix, the root "stel-" gave rise to words like "thel," meaning "to intend, purpose, or resolve," and "þelma," which signifies a "fixed idea" or "will." In essence, all these terms, including Ecthelion's name, are connected to the concept of steadfastness, firmness, and a resolute will.

quote: It is said that he was the first of Men to reach the Great Sea, and that none, save the Eldar, have ever felt more deeply the longing that it brings.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: It is said that he was the first of Men to reach the Great Sea, and that none, save the Eldar, have ever felt more deeply the longing that it brings.

In fact, his desire for the sea was so profound that no other human has ever felt it as intensely as he did; only the Eldar (an ancient, perhaps elven, race) are said to have experienced a similar or even deeper connection to the sea.

quote: So great was her sorrow, as the Music unfolded, that her song turned to lamentation long before its end, and the sound of mourning was woven into the themes of the World before it began. But she does not weep for herself; and those who hearken to her learn pity, and endurance in hope.

quote: Every writer making a secondary world wishes in some measure to be a real maker, or hopes that he is drawing on reality: hopes that the peculiar quality of this secondary world (if not all the details) are derived from Reality, or are flowing into it.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Every writer making a secondary world wishes in some measure to be a real maker, or hopes that he is drawing on reality: hopes that the peculiar quality of this secondary world (if not all the details) are derived from Reality, or are flowing into it.
summary: Writers who create fictional worlds, like in fantasy or science fiction, don't just want to invent stories; they deeply hope their creations feel genuinely meaningful and connected to something true. They wish their invented worlds have a real substance, as if they are tapping into a deeper reality for inspiration. This means they hope the unique spirit or quality of their fictional world, even if not every small detail, either comes from a fundamental truth or somehow contributes to a larger reality, making their work feel more profound than simple make-believe.

There, the weary eyes finally rest upon comforting, familiar scenes: smiling pastures, well-known trees, and beloved hills.

quote: If you really want to know what Middle-earth is based on, it’s my wonder and delight in the earth as it is, particularly the natural earth.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: If you really want to know what Middle-earth is based on, it’s my wonder and delight in the earth as it is, particularly the natural earth.
summary: The author explains that the true inspiration for Middle-earth comes from his profound sense of wonder and delight in the real world, especially its natural elements. He means that his love and appreciation for the beauty and magic of the Earth as it naturally exists – its landscapes, plants, and wildness – are the fundamental basis for his fictional world.

quote: For of us is required a blind trust, and a hope without assurance, knowing not what lies before us in a little while.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: For of us is required a blind trust, and a hope without assurance, knowing not what lies before us in a little while.
summary: This quote suggests that we are required to have complete trust, even when we don't understand or have any reason to believe in what's coming. We also need to maintain hope, even if there's no guarantee that things will turn out well. This is because we have no idea what the future holds, not even what will happen very soon.

quote: Incomparably greater than the power of Sauron, concentrated in the One Ring, Morgoth's power was dispersed into the very matter of Arda: "The whole of Middle-earth was Morgoth's Ring.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Incomparably greater than the power of Sauron, concentrated in the One Ring, Morgoth's power was dispersed into the very matter of Arda: "The whole of Middle-earth was Morgoth's Ring.
summary: This quote explains that Morgoth's power was far greater and more widespread than Sauron's. While Sauron concentrated much of his power into a single object, the One Ring, Morgoth's immense power was not contained in one place but was instead dispersed throughout the very matter and fabric of the entire world, Arda (Middle-earth). This means his dark influence was woven into everything, making the whole world itself like his own vast, pervasive "Ring" of power.

quote: Frodo has been touched by the weapons of the Enemy,' said Strider, 'and there is some poison or evil at work that is beyond my skill to drive out. But do not give up hope, Sam!

quote: He slept curled up on the hard rock more soundly than ever he had done on his feather-bed in his own little hole at home.
