However, his dreams were restless; all night he wandered through his own house, searching for something important that he couldn't find or even remember what it looked like.

quote: A fool, but an honest fool, you remain, Peregrin Took. Wiser ones might have done worse in such a pass.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: A fool, but an honest fool, you remain, Peregrin Took. Wiser ones might have done worse in such a pass.
summary: This quote tells Peregrin Took that he is foolish, but emphasizes that his foolishness comes from an honest and good place. Despite his lack of wisdom, the speaker believes that in a difficult situation, Peregrin's actions were surprisingly not bad. In fact, they suggest that someone considered wiser might have actually done worse in the exact same predicament. Essentially, while Peregrin might be naive, his good intentions led to an outcome that was acceptable, and perhaps even better than what a more intelligent person might have achieved under pressure.

quote: I found it is the small everyday deeds of ordinary folk that keep the darkness at bay… small acts of kindness and love.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: I found it is the small everyday deeds of ordinary folk that keep the darkness at bay… small acts of kindness and love.
summary: This quote suggests that the world is protected from evil and despair not by grand, heroic gestures, but by the consistent, small acts of kindness and love performed by ordinary people every day. It emphasizes that these simple, compassionate deeds, done by regular individuals, are powerful enough to keep negativity at bay and make a real difference.

quote: The essence of a fallen world is that the best cannot be attained by free enjoyment, or by what is called "self-realization" (usually a nice name for self-indulgence, wholly inimical to the realization of other selves); but by denial, by suffering.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: The essence of a fallen world is that the best cannot be attained by free enjoyment, or by what is called "self-realization" (usually a nice name for self-indulgence, wholly inimical to the realization of other selves); but by denial, by suffering.
summary: In a world that is imperfect or "fallen," the quote suggests that true fulfillment and the best outcomes aren't achieved by freely enjoying oneself or by focusing solely on what's called "self-realization." The author believes "self-realization" is often just a polite way to describe self-indulgence, which actually hinders our ability to understand and connect with other people. Instead, the quote argues that genuine growth and the attainment of the best things come through self-denial (giving things up) and by enduring suffering or hardship.

quote: remember Húrin; for without mortal Men the Elves shall not prevail against the Balrogs and the Orcs.

quote:
But when Aragorn arose all that beheld him gazed in silence, for it seemed to
them that he was revealed to them now for the first time. Tall as the sea-kings of old, he
stood above all that were near; ancient of days he seemed and yet in the flower of
manhood; and wisdom sat upon his brow, and strength and healing were in his hands,
and a light was about him. And then Faramir cried:
'Behold the King!'
And in that moment all the trumpets were blown, and the King Elessar went
forth and came to the barrier, and Húrin of the Keys thrust it back; and amid the music
of harp and of viol and of flute and the singing of clear voices the King passed through
the flower-laden streets, and came to the Citadel, and entered in; and the banner of the Tree and the Stars was unfurled upon the topmost tower, and the reign of King Elessar
began, of which many songs have told.
In his time the City was made more fair than it had ever been, even in the days of
its first glory; and it was filled with trees and with fountains, and its gates were
wrought of mithril and steel, and its streets were paved with white marble; and the Folk
of the Mountain laboured in it, and the Folk of the Wood rejoiced to come there; and all
was healed and made good, and the houses were filled with men and women and the
laughter of children, and no window was blind nor any courtyard empty; and after the
ending of the Third Age of the world into the new age it preserved the memory and the
glory of the years that were gone.

quote: Now Melkor began the delving and building of a vast fortress, deep under Earth, beneath dark mountains where the beams of Illuin were cold and dim. That stronghold was named Utumno. And though the Valar knew naught of it as yet, nonetheless the evil of Melkor and the blight of his hatred flowed out thence, and the Spring of Arda was marred. Green things fell sick and rotted, and rivers were choked with weeds and slime, and fens were made, rank and poisonous, the breeding place of flies; and forests grew dark and perilous, the haunts of fear; and beasts became monsters of horn and ivory and dyed the earth with blood. Then the Valar knew indeed that Melkor was at work again, and they sought for his hiding place. But Melkor, trusting in the strength of Utumno and the might of his servants, came forth suddenly to war, and struck the first blow, ere the Valar were prepared; and he assailed the lights of Illuin and Ormal, and cast down their pillars and broke their lamps. In the overthrow of the mighty pillars lands were broken and seas arose in tumult; and when the lamps were spilled destroying flame was poured out over the Earth. And the shape of Arda and the symmetry of its waters and its lands was marred in that time, so that the first designs of the Valar were never after restored.

Then the Valar knew indeed that Melkor was at work again, and they sought for his hiding place. But Melkor, trusting in the strength of Utumno and the might of his servants, came forth suddenly to war, and struck the first blow, ere the Valar were prepared; and he assailed the lights of Illuin and Ormal, and cast down their pillars and broke their lamps. In the overthrow of the mighty pillars lands were broken and seas arose in tumult; and when the lamps were spilled destroying flame was poured out over the Earth. And the shape of Arda and the symmetry of its waters and its lands was marred in that time, so that the first designs of the Valar were never after restored.
summary: Melkor secretly built a vast fortress called Utumno deep underground. From this hidden stronghold, his evil spread, corrupting the world: plants sickened, rivers became choked, forests grew dangerous, and animals turned into monsters. Although the Valar (the good powers) didn't initially know about Utumno, they soon realized Melkor was active again. Before they could prepare, Melkor launched a surprise attack, destroying the great lights of Illuin and Ormal. This act caused immense devastation, breaking lands and stirring seas, permanently altering the world's original shape and beauty.

quote: What a mess are we in now! We! I only wish it was we: it is horrible being all alone.

quote:

quote: Fantasy is a natural human activity. It certainly does not destroy or even insult Reason; and it does not either blunt the appetite for, nor obscure the perception of scientific verity. Even more remarkably, the music and its echoes then extended out into the empty "Void" – the space of nothingness – and in doing so, transformed it so that it was no longer truly empty. Essentially, music brought existence to what was once void.

quote: I go now to my long rest in the timeless halls beyond the seas and the Mountains of Aman. It will be long ere I am seen among the Noldor again; and it may be that we shall not meet a second time in death or life, for the fates of our kindreds are apart. Farewell!
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: I go now to my long rest in the timeless halls beyond the seas and the Mountains of Aman. It will be long ere I am seen among the Noldor again; and it may be that we shall not meet a second time in death or life, for the fates of our kindreds are apart. Farewell!
summary: The speaker is saying a final goodbye, explaining they are leaving for a peaceful, eternal resting place far away. They believe it will be a very long time before they see their people, the Noldor, again, and it's likely they will never meet again, whether in life or death. This is because their destinies are now entirely separate.

quote: Indeed the mind of Ilúvatar concerning you is not known to the Valar, and he has not revealed all things that are to come. But this we hold to be true, that your home is not here, neither in the land of Aman nor anywhere within the Circles of the World. And the Doom of Men, that they should depart, was at first a gift of Ilúvatar. It became a grief to them only because coming under the shadow of Morgoth it seemed to them that they were surrounded by a great darkness, of which they grew afraid; and some grew wilful and proud and would not yield, until life was reft from them.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Indeed the mind of Ilúvatar concerning you is not known to the Valar, and he has not revealed all things that are to come. But this we hold to be true, that your home is not here, neither in the land of Aman nor anywhere within the Circles of the World. And the Doom of Men, that they should depart, was at first a gift of Ilúvatar. It became a grief to them only because coming under the shadow of Morgoth it seemed to them that they were surrounded by a great darkness, of which they grew afraid; and some grew wilful and proud and would not yield, until life was reft from them.
summary: This passage explains that even the powerful Valar don't fully understand Ilúvatar's (God's) complete plan for humanity, but one thing is certain: humanity's true home is not in this physical world. The fate of humans to eventually die and depart was originally a gift from Ilúvatar. However, under the dark influence of Morgoth, this gift became a source of fear and sorrow, as death seemed like an overwhelming darkness. This fear caused some people to become stubborn and proud, resisting their inevitable end until death finally claimed them.

quote: We must do without hope,’ he said. ‘At least we may yet be avenged. Let us gird ourselves and weep no more! Come! We have a long road, and much to do.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: We must do without hope,’ he said. ‘At least we may yet be avenged. Let us gird ourselves and weep no more! Come! We have a long road, and much to do.
summary: The speaker declares that they can no longer rely on hope, as it's gone or useless. Instead, their new purpose is to seek revenge or justice for past wrongs. They urge everyone to stop grieving and feeling sorry for themselves, and to instead prepare themselves for action. The message is to move forward with determination, acknowledging that they have a long, difficult path ahead and many tasks to accomplish.

quote:
He heard himself crying out: Never, never! Or was it: Verily I come, I come to you? He could not tell. Then as a flash from some other point of power there came to his mind another thought: Take it off! Take it off! Fool, take it off! Take off the Ring!
The two powers strove in him. For a moment, perfectly balanced between their piercing points, he writhed, tormented. Suddenly he was aware of himself again. Frodo, neither the Voice nor the Eye: free to choose, and with one remaining instant in which to do so. He took the Ring off his finger.
prompt_template:
Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: He heard himself crying out: Never, never! Or was it: Verily I come, I come to you? He could not tell. The two powers strove in him. For a moment, perfectly balanced between their piercing points, he writhed, tormented. Suddenly he was aware of himself again. Frodo, neither the Voice nor the Eye: free to choose, and with one remaining instant in which to do so. He took the Ring off his finger.
summary: The character, Frodo, was caught in a fierce internal struggle, confused by conflicting urges within him – one pulling him towards surrender or acceptance, and another, urgent voice commanding him to remove the Ring. This intense mental battle caused him great torment as these two powerful forces fought for control. However, in a crucial moment of clarity, he suddenly became aware of his true self, Frodo, separate from these overwhelming influences. Realizing he had the freedom to choose and only a brief instant to act, he decisively took the Ring off his finger.

quote: Revenge! he snorted, and the light of his eyes lit the hall from floor to ceiling like scarlet lightning. Revenge! The King under the Mountain is dead and where are his kin that dare seek revenge? Girion Lord of Dale is dead, and I have eaten his people like a wolf among sheep, and where are his sons’ sons that dare approach me? I kill where I wish and none dare resist. I laid low the warriors of old and their like is not in the world today. Then I was but young and tender. Now I am old and strong, strong, strong, Thief in the Shadows! he gloated. My armour is like tenfold shields, my teeth are swords, my claws spears, the shock of my tail a thunderbolt, my wings a hurricane, and my breath death!
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Revenge! he snorted, and the light of his eyes lit the hall from floor to ceiling like scarlet lightning. Revenge! It proudly declares that it killed the King under the Mountain and Lord Girion of Dale, devouring their people like a wolf, and none of their kin have dared to seek retribution. It proclaims absolute power, stating it kills as it wishes with no resistance, and that it's now older and far stronger than when it defeated the legendary warriors of old. Addressing an unseen "Thief in the Shadows," it gloats about its terrifying features: armor like impenetrable shields, teeth like swords, claws like spears, a tail that strikes like lightning, wings that create hurricanes, and breath that brings death.

quote:
It’s like in the great stories, Mr. Frodo. The ones that really mattered. Full of darkness and danger they were. And sometimes you didn’t want to know the end. Because how could the end be happy? How could the world go back to the way it was when so much bad had happened?

But in the end, it’s only a passing thing, this shadow. Even darkness must pass. A new day will come. And when the sun shines it will shine out the clearer. Those were the stories that stayed with you. That meant something. Even if you were too small to understand why. But I think, Mr. Frodo, I do understand. I know now. Folk in those stories had lots of chances of turning back only they didn’t. Because they were holding on to something.

FRODO: What are we holding on to, Sam?

SAM: That there’s some good in this world, Mr. Frodo. And it’s worth fighting for.

Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: It’s like in the great stories, Mr. Frodo. The ones that really mattered. Full of darkness and danger they were. Those were the stories that stayed with you. That meant something. Even if you were too small to understand why. But I think, Mr. Frodo, I do understand. I know now. Folk in those stories had lots of chances of turning back only they didn’t. Because they were holding on to something.

summary: This quote reflects on great stories where characters face immense darkness and danger, making a happy ending seem impossible. These powerful stories are memorable because their characters, despite many chances to quit, persevere. Their unwavering resolve comes from holding onto the belief that there is still good in the world, and that this good is worth fighting for above all else.

quote: Cheer up Thorin and Company! This is your expedition after all. Think of the treasure at the end, and forget the forest and the dragon, at any rate until tomorrow morning!
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Cheer up Thorin and Company! This is your expedition after all. Think of the treasure at the end, and forget the forest and the dragon, at any rate until tomorrow morning!

For now, they should put aside their worries about the challenging forest and the dangerous dragon, and only think about those problems again tomorrow morning.

quote: How do I feel?' he cried. ' Well, I don't know how to say it. I feel, I feel' – he waved his arms in the air – 'I feel like spring after winter, and sun on the leaves; and like trumpets and harps and all the songs I have ever heard!' He stopped and he turned towards his master.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: How do I feel?' he cried. ' Well, I don't know how to say it. He stopped and he turned towards his master.
summary: The character, when asked about his feelings, struggled to find the right words to describe his overwhelming emotions. He expressed that he felt like the refreshing arrival of spring after winter, the comforting warmth of sun on leaves, and the grand, joyful sound of trumpets, harps, and all the beautiful songs he had ever heard. In essence, he was experiencing an intense, exhilarating, and profoundly positive happiness that was almost beyond words, a feeling of complete renewal and vibrant delight.

quote: A única coisa que temos que decidir é o que faremos com o tempo que nos é dado.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: A única coisa que temos que decidir é o que faremos com o tempo que nos é dado.
summary: This quote means that, at its core, the only real decision we have to make in life is how we choose to use the time we are given. While we don't control how much time we get, we are completely responsible for deciding what we do with it – how we spend our days, what we focus on, and what we make of our opportunities. It highlights that our actions and choices regarding our time are the most crucial decisions we face.

quote: ...present and yet remote, a living vision of that which has already been left far behind by the flowing streams of Time.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: ...present and yet remote, a living vision of that which has already been left far behind by the flowing streams of Time.
summary: This quote describes something that is visible right now, but also feels distant and out of reach. It's like seeing a clear, lifelike image of something that actually belongs to the past, something that the unstoppable flow of time has long since moved beyond and left behind.

quote: What is the house of Eorl but a thatched barn where brigands drink in the reek, and their brats roll on the floor among the dogs? Too long have they escaped the gibbet themselves. But the noose comes, slow in the drawing, tight and hard in the end. Hang if you will!
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: What is the house of Eorl but a thatched barn where brigands drink in the reek, and their brats roll on the floor among the dogs? summary: The speaker utterly dismisses the House of Eorl, calling it nothing more than a filthy barn where criminals and their unruly children live like animals. They believe its members are lawless people who have deserved to be executed for too long. The speaker warns that their inevitable punishment, death by hanging, is approaching slowly but will ultimately be a harsh and unavoidable end. Finally, the speaker defiantly tells them to "hang if you will," implying their doom is certain and they might as well accept it.

quote: Ride, ride to ruin and the world's ending!
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Ride, ride to ruin and the world's ending!
summary: This quote expresses a grim and urgent warning. It suggests that a continuous, perhaps unstoppable, course of action or way of life is leading directly towards utter destruction and collapse. The phrase implies a desperate and inevitable rush towards not just personal failure, but a catastrophic end for everything, signaling the ultimate downfall of the world.

quote: One of its sources [Leaf by Niggle] was a great-limbed poplar tree that I could see even lying in bed. It was suddenly lopped and mutilated by its owner, I do not know why. It is cut down now, a less barbarous punishment for any crimes it might have been accused of, such as being large and alive. I do not think it had any friends, or any mourners, except myself and a pair of owls.

quote: Travellers scowl at us, and countrymen give us scornful names. 'Strider' I am to one fat man who lives within a day's march of foes that would freeze his heart, or lay his little town in ruin, if he were not guarded ceaselessly. Yet we would not have it otherwise. If simple folk are free from care and fear, simple they will be, and we must be secret to keep them so.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Travellers scowl at us, and countrymen give us scornful names. 'Strider' I am to one fat man who lives within a day's march of foes that would freeze his heart, or lay his little town in ruin, if he were not guarded ceaselessly. Yet we would not have it otherwise. If simple folk are free from care and fear, simple they will be, and we must be secret to keep them so.
summary: The speaker explains that ordinary people and travelers often look down on them and call them insulting names like 'Strider.' Despite this, the speaker and their kind are secretly and constantly guarding these people from terrible dangers they don't even know exist. They choose to do this thankless, hidden work because they believe it's essential for simple folk to remain carefree and innocent, unaware of the threats that would otherwise terrify them or destroy their homes. They accept being misunderstood and unappreciated as the price for keeping others safe and peaceful.

quote:
For still there are so many things
that I have never seen:
in every wood in every spring
there is a different green.

I sit beside the fire and think
of people long ago,
and people who will see a world
that I shall never know.

and people who will see a world

summary: This quote expresses a feeling of wonder and humility about the world. The speaker feels there's an endless amount to see and experience, even in familiar things like nature, where every spring brings a unique shade of green. Sitting and reflecting, they also contemplate the vast sweep of time, thinking about those who lived long ago and the future generations who will experience a world the speaker will never know, acknowledging the limited scope of their own life within the grand flow of existence.

quote: If this is to end in fire, then we should all burn together.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: If this is to end in fire, then we should all burn together.
summary: This quote means that if a situation is destined to end in complete disaster or ruin, everyone involved should face that terrible outcome together. It emphasizes a sense of shared fate and solidarity, suggesting that no one should be spared while others suffer the consequences. Basically, if things are going to fall apart, everyone should be in it together and experience the end as one.

quote: Though mortal Men have little life beside the span of the Elves, they would rather spend it in battle than fly or submit. The defiance of Húrin Thalion is a great deed; and though Morgoth slay the doer he cannot make the deed not to have been. Even the Lords of the West will honour it; and is it not written into the history of Arda, which neither Morgoth nor Manwë can unwrite?
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Though mortal Men have little life beside the span of the Elves, they would rather spend it in battle than fly or submit. Even the Lords of the West will honour it; and is it not written into the history of Arda, which neither Morgoth nor Manwë can unwrite?
summary: Despite their short lives compared to Elves, mortal men often choose to spend their brief time fighting bravely rather than submitting or fleeing. The defiance of Húrin Thalion is presented as a prime example of this spirit. The quote highlights that even if an evil power like Morgoth slays the doer, the courageous act itself cannot be undone or erased. Such a deed will be honored even by the highest powers and becomes an unchangeable part of history, something neither good nor evil forces can erase.

quote: Let us remember that a traitor may betray himself and do good that he does not intend. It can be so, sometimes

In doing so, their negative actions, despite being meant for harm, could accidentally lead to a positive or beneficial outcome that they never intended. It means that sometimes, bad deeds can unexpectedly backfire in a way that produces good results.

quote: Perhaps you could call her perilous, because she's so strong in herself. You, you could dash yourself to pieces on her, like a ship on a rock.

Anyone who tries to challenge or oppose her will be completely defeated and broken, much like a ship that would be shattered into pieces if it crashed against a solid, immovable rock.

quote: Lo que el corazón desea no son recuerdos. Eso es sólo un espejo, aunque sea tan claro como Kheledzaram.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Lo que el corazón desea no son recuerdos. Eso es sólo un espejo, aunque sea tan claro como Kheledzaram.
summary: This quote suggests that what your heart truly desires isn't just memories of the past. Instead, memories, no matter how vivid or clear, are simply reflections, like looking into a perfect mirror. They show you what was, but they aren't the actual thing your heart yearns for. Your heart seeks something more than just a copy of what once existed; it looks for the real, present experience or the original essence, not just a reflection.

quote: I think I’m quite ready for another adventure.

summary: This quote means the speaker feels completely prepared and eager to embark on a new experience. They are ready to leave behind their current situation or previous activities and are enthusiastic about starting a fresh, exciting journey or taking on a new challenge.

quote: Frodo looked up at the Elf standing tall above him, as he gazed into the night, seeking a mark to shoot at. His head was dark, crowned with sharp white stars that glittered in the black pools of the sky behind.

From Frodo's low perspective, the Elf's dark head appeared silhouetted against the night sky, and the bright, sharp stars sparkling in the blackness behind him looked like a crown on his head.

quote: This book is thus primarily addressed to such readers as may perhaps recall that the hide of Shelob was so horrendously hard that it ‘could not be pierced by any strength of men, not though Elf or Dwarf should forge the steel or the the children of húrin hand of Beren or of Túrin wield it’, or that Elrond named Túrin to Frodo at Rivendell as one of ‘the mighty Elf-friends of old’; but know no more of him.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: This book is thus primarily addressed to such readers as may perhaps recall that the hide of Shelob was so horrendously hard that it ‘could not be pierced by any strength of men, not though Elf or Dwarf should forge the steel or the the children of húrin hand of Beren or of Túrin wield it’, or that Elrond named Túrin to Frodo at Rivendell as one of ‘the mighty Elf-friends of old’; but know no more of him.
summary: This book is written for readers who already have some familiarity with Tolkien's world. They might remember specific details, like how incredibly tough Shelob's hide was, and that legendary figures like Túrin were mentioned as so powerful they *still* couldn't pierce it. They might also recall Elrond speaking to Frodo and referring to Túrin as one of the great heroes of old, a "mighty Elf-friend." However, despite these intriguing glimpses, these readers don't know the full story of Túrin, and this book aims to tell it.

quote: All the same, I wish it was over for good or ill,’ said Pippin. ‘I am no warrior at all and dislike any thought of battle; but waiting on the edge of one that I can’t escape is worst of all.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: All the same, I wish it was over for good or ill,’ said Pippin. ‘I am no warrior at all and dislike any thought of battle; but waiting on the edge of one that I can’t escape is worst of all.
summary: Pippin expresses his strong desire for the current situation, which involves an unavoidable battle, to simply be over, no matter the outcome. He admits he's not a fighter and dislikes the very thought of battle. However, for him, the most agonizing part isn't the fight itself, but the dread and uncertainty of waiting on the brink of a conflict he knows he cannot escape.

quote: The mother of our particular hobbit—what is a hobbit? I suppose hobbits need some description nowadays, since they have become rare and shy of the Big People, as they call us. They are (or were) a little people, about half our height, and smaller than the bearded Dwarves. Hobbits have no beards. There is little or no magic about them, except the ordinary everyday sort which helps them to disappear quietly and quickly when large stupid folk like you and me come blundering along, making a noise like elephants which they can hear a mile off.

They have become rare and tend to avoid humans, whom they call "Big People." Hobbits possess very little magic, except for a practical ability to disappear quickly and quietly. They use this skill to avoid noisy humans, whose loud movements they can hear from far away.

Specifically, Mîm added "three great cooking-pots," meaning three large cooking vessels, to the existing supplies or possessions.

quote: As a small token only of your friendship Sauron asks this, he said:  that you should find this thief, such was his word, and get from him, willing or no, a little ring, the least of rings, that once he stole. It is but a trifle that Sauron fancies, and an earnest of your good will.

summary: Sauron is asking for a small favor as a sign of friendship. He wants the listener to find a specific thief who stole a tiny ring, which he calls "the least of rings." The listener must then get this ring back from the thief, whether they are willing to give it up or not. Sauron claims it's just a small, unimportant item he fancies, and that retrieving it will prove the listener's good will.

quote: Mere flight in a dream you say. In dream many desires are revealed; and desire may be the last flicker of Estel.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Mere flight in a dream you say. In dream many desires are revealed; and desire may be the last flicker of Estel.
summary: Someone might dismiss a dream, like flying, as just a simple, unimportant fantasy. However, the speaker argues that dreams are significant because they often reveal our hidden desires and deepest longings. More profoundly, the speaker suggests that such a desire, even if it feels small or fleeting, could represent the very last spark of hope (Estel) that someone holds onto.

quote: It was in this way that he learned where Gandalf had been to; for he overheard the words of the wizard to Elrond. quote: I am a servant of the Secret Fire, wielder of the flame of Anor.

Essentially, the speaker is a powerful agent or guardian of a cosmic, good force, wielding its light and strength.

quote: He was fingering his great horn.

However, due to the common slang use of "horn" to refer to an erection, and "fingering" implying manipulation, the quote also carries a strong sexual innuendo, suggesting the person was masturbating. Without further context, the exact meaning remains ambiguous.

quote: Elrond knew all about runes of every kind. That day he looked at the swords they had brought from the trolls' lair, and he said: "These are not troll-make. Keep them well!
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Elrond knew all about runes of every kind. That day he looked at the swords they had brought from the trolls' lair, and he said: "These are not troll-make. They are old swords, very old swords of High Elves of the West, my kin. They were made in Gondolin for the Goblin-wars. They must have come from a dragon's hoard or goblin plunder, for dragons and goblins destroyed that city many ages ago. This, Thorin, the runes name Orcrist, the Goblin-cleaver in the ancient tongue of Gondolin; it was a famous blade. This, Gandalf, was Glamdring, Foe-hammer that the kind of Gondolin once wore. Keep them well!
summary: Elrond, who was very knowledgeable about ancient runes, examined the swords found in the trolls' lair. He quickly determined that they were not made by trolls, but were instead very old blades crafted by his own kin, the High Elves of the West, specifically in the ancient city of Gondolin for wars against goblins. He believed the swords, named Orcrist (the "Goblin-cleaver") for Thorin and Glamdring (the "Foe-hammer") for Gandalf, must have come from a dragon's hoard or goblin plunder, as dragons and goblins had destroyed Gondolin ages ago. Elrond then urged them to keep these famous and legendary weapons well.

quote: Slowly his hand went to his bosom, and slowly he held aloft the Phial of Galadriel. For a moment it glimmered, faint as a rising star struggling in heavy earthward mists, and then as its power waxed, and hope grew in Frodo’s mind, it began to burn, and kindled to a silver flame, a minute heart of dazzling light, as though Eärendil had himself come down from the high sunset paths with the last Silmaril upon his brow. The darkness receded from it, until it seemed to shine in the centre of a globe of airy crystal, and the hand that held it sparkled with white fire. Frodo gazed in wonder at this marvellous gift that he had so long carried, not guessing its full worth and potency.

Frodo gazed in wonder, finally understanding the immense power of this marvelous gift he had carried for so long.

quote:
Sam: I know. It’s all wrong. By rights we shouldn’t even be here. But we are. It’s like in the great stories, Mr. Frodo. The ones that really mattered. Full of darkness and danger, they were. And sometimes you didn’t want to know the end. Because how could the end be happy? How could the world go back to the way it was when so much bad had happened? But in the end, it’s only a passing thing, this shadow. Even darkness must pass. A new day will come. And when the sun shines it will shine out the clearer. Those were the stories that stayed with you. That meant something, even if you were too small to understand why. But I think, Mr. Frodo, I do understand. I know now. Folk in those stories had lots of chances of turning back, only they didn’t. They kept going. Because they were holding on to something.
Frodo: What are we holding onto, Sam?
Sam: That there’s some good in this world, Mr. Frodo… and it’s worth fighting for.

quote: Already the Ring tempted him, gnawing at his will and reason. Wild fantasies arose in his mind; and he saw Samwise the Strong, Hero of the Age, striding with a flaming sword across the darkened land, and armies flocking to his call as he marched to the overthrow of Barad-dur. And then all the clouds rolled away, and the white sun shone, and at his command the vale of Gorgoroth became a garden of flowers and trees and brought forth fruit. He had only to put on the Ring and claim it for his own, and all this could be. In that hour of trial it was his love of his master that helped most to hold him firm; but also deep down in him lived still unconquered his plain hobbit-sense: he knew in the core of his heart that he was not large enough to bear such a burden, even if such visions were not a mere cheat to betray him. The one small garden of a free gardener was all his need and due, not a garden swollen to a realm; his own hands to use, not the hands of others to command. 'And anyway all these notions are only a trick, he said to himself.

quote:
It had a perfectly round door like a porthole,
painted green, with a shiny yellow brass knob in the exact middle. The door opened on to a
tube-shaped hall like a tunnel: a very comfortable tunnel without smoke, with panelled walls, and floors tiled and carpeted, provided with polished chairs, and lots and lots of pegs for hats and coats — the hobbit was fond of visitors. The tunnel wound on and on, going fairly but not quite straight into the side of the hill — The Hill, as all the people for many miles round called it — and many little round doors opened out of it, first on one side and then on another. No going upstairs for the hobbit: bedrooms, bathrooms, cellars, pantries (lots of
these), wardrobes (he had whole rooms
devoted to clothes), kitchens, dining-rooms, all were on the same floor, and indeed on the
same passage. The best rooms were all on the left-hand side (going in), for these were the only ones to have windows, deep-set round windows looking over his garden, and
meadows beyond, sloping down to the river.

This well-furnished hall, with paneled walls, tiled and carpeted floors, and plenty of pegs for coats, showed the hobbit's fondness for visitors. The tunnel gently wound into the side of The Hill, with many smaller round doors leading off it. All the rooms—including bedrooms, kitchens, and many pantries—were conveniently located on this single, winding passage, meaning there were no stairs. The best rooms, situated on the left, had deep-set round windows that offered pleasant views of the garden, meadows, and river.

quote: It is also reflected in the commitment to the belief that everything, even Morgoth himself, was as created good, But that due to the free will possessed by every creature with a rational mind, they could fall: as one Vala and various Maiar, and Men corporately, did; and even Manwë, had he asserted his own will and judgement over Eru’s, would likewise have fallen.

quote: You sit in these halls with a crown upon your head, and yet you are less of a man than you have ever been.

quote: Many that live deserve death. And some that die deserve life. Can you give it to them? Then do not be too eager to deal out death in judgement. For even the very wise cannot see all ends. I have not much hope that Gollum can be cured before he dies, but there is a chance of it.

summary: This quote advises us to be incredibly cautious and humble when judging others, especially when it comes to deciding who deserves to live or die. Even the wisest people cannot foresee all future outcomes or understand a person's full potential for change. Therefore, we should not be quick to condemn or "deal out death," because even for someone seemingly beyond hope, like Gollum, there might still be a small chance for redemption or a different path that we cannot foresee.

quote: The Sea has no shore. There is no Light in the West.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: The Sea has no shore. There is no Light in the West.

Following this, "There is no Light in the West" means there's no hope, no sign of relief, or no positive future coming, as the west is where the sun sets, bringing darkness. Together, these lines convey a profound sense of being trapped in a seemingly endless and hopeless predicament, with no possibility of things improving or finding a way out.

quote:

prompt_template:

'So I can well believe, ' said Smaug, 'but that is hardly your usual name.'
'I am the clue-finder, the web-cutter, the stinging fly. I was chosen for the lucky number.'

'I am he that buries his friends alive and drowns them and draws them alive again from water. I came from the end of a bag, but no bag went over me.
summary: In this exchange, a speaker, likely Bilbo Baggins, cryptically describes himself to the skeptical dragon Smaug, without revealing his true name. He boasts of his humble origins "under the hill" and his wide-ranging travels, claiming he can "walk unseen." He then takes on titles like "clue-finder" and "web-cutter," suggesting he is resourceful and effective in his tasks, and was "chosen for the lucky number." He continues by describing how he ingeniously saved his companions by hiding them in barrels, putting them into water, and then retrieving them safely. Finally, he hints at his family name, stating he "came from the end of a bag" (Baggins), but emphasizes that he has not been defeated or captured. Throughout, Smaug reacts with scorn and disbelief to these grand, yet riddling, self-descriptions.

quote: Get out, you old Wight! Vanish in the sunlight! Shrivel like the cold mist, like the winds go wailing, Out into the barren lands far beyond the mountains! Come never here again! Instead, they can leave a lasting scar or a lingering feeling that stays with us, reminding us of what we've been through.

quote: The fate of Men after death, maybe, is not in the hands of the Valar, nor was all foretold in the Music of the Ainur.

quote: On all this Bilbo looked with misery. Firstly, he hoped it would offer him the best chance to escape if things got too dangerous. quote: Nigdy nie drwij z żywego smoka, Bilbo głupcze
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Nigdy nie drwij z żywego smoka, Bilbo głupcze
summary: The Polish quote, "Nigdy nie drwij z żywego smoka, Bilbo głupcze," translates to "Never mock a living dragon, Bilbo, you fool." This is a powerful warning that tells someone, specifically Bilbo, not to underestimate or provoke a dangerous and formidable creature. It implies that making fun of a living dragon would be an incredibly foolish act, leading to very severe consequences. Essentially, it's a reminder to be cautious and show respect when dealing with powerful threats, rather than acting unwisely.

quote: They had begun to forget: forget their own beginnings and legends, forget what little they had known about the greatness of the world. And anyway you must begin at some point, with some one person. I dare say he was chosen and I was only chosen to choose him; but I picked out Bilbo.

quote: But Ilúvatar knew that Men, being set amid the turmoils of the powers of the world, would stray often, and would not use their gifts in harmony; and he said, ‘These too in their time shall find that all that they do redounds at the end only to the glory of my work.’ Yet the Elves believe that Men are often a grief to Manwë, who knows most of the mind of Ilúvatar; for it seems to the Elves that Men resemble Melkor most of all the Ainur, although he has ever feared and hated them, even those that served him.

However, the Elves see things differently: they believe humans often cause sadness for Manwë, who is most attuned to Ilúvatar's thoughts. This is because the Elves feel that humans resemble Melkor, the great evil, more than anyone else, even though Melkor himself has always feared and hated them, even his own followers.

quote: All that glitters is not gold
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: All that glitters is not gold

Therefore, it's wise to look beyond the superficial and examine things more closely before making judgments or trusting them.

quote:

prompt_template:
Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Trente chevaux sur une colline rouge;

Puis ils frappent leur marque,
Ensuite ils restent immobiles.

(Les dents)
summary: This quote is a clever riddle that uses a metaphor to describe teeth. It imagines "thirty horses" (representing the teeth) residing on a "red hill" (the gums or mouth). The poem then details their actions: first, they chew or munch; then, they bite down firmly; and finally, they remain still. The parenthetical note reveals that these "horses" are, in fact, the teeth, highlighting their functions from chewing to resting.

quote: These words shall go with the gift,’ she said. ‘I do not foretell, for all foretelling is now vain: on the one hand lies darkness, and on the other only hope. quote:
The heart of man is not compound of lies,
but draws some wisdom from the only Wise,
and still recalls Him. Though now long estranged,
Man is not wholly lost nor wholly changed.
Dis-graced he may be, yet is not de-throned,
and keeps the rags of lordship once he owned:
Man, Sub-creator, the refracted light
through whom is splintered from a single White
to many hues, and endlessly combined
in living shapes that move from mind to mind.
Though all the crannies of the world we filled
with Elves and Goblins, though we dared to build
Gods and their houses out of dark and light,
and sowed the seed of dragons – 'twas our right
(used or misused). That right has not decayed:
we make still by the law in which we're made.

This powerful urge to create is not merely a hobby but an inherent, undiminished right, fundamental to our very being, as we create according to the same laws by which we ourselves were made.

quote: In the deep places he gives thought to music great and terrible; and the echo of that music runs through all the veins of the world in sorrow and in joy; for if joyful is the fountain that rises in the sun, its springs are in the wells of sorrow unfathomed at the foundations of the Earth.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: In the deep places he gives thought to music great and terrible; and the echo of that music runs through all the veins of the world in sorrow and in joy; for if joyful is the fountain that rises in the sun, its springs are in the wells of sorrow unfathomed at the foundations of the Earth.
summary: This quote suggests that a profound, fundamental "music"—which is both magnificent and terrifying—originates from the deepest, most hidden parts of existence. The influence of this deep music then spreads throughout the entire world, shaping all human emotions, both sorrow and joy. In essence, joy is deeply rooted in and arises from profound sadness.

quote:
Then what is Durin's Day?" asked Elrond.

After failing to reach the source of the trouble through a small hole, he bursts from his deep lair with a mighty roar, speeding through the mountain's passages towards the main gate.

quote: Dividing the upland into two there marched a double line of unshaped standing stones that dwindled into the dusk and vanished in the trees. He wondered what they could be, and he hoped that the king was

quote:
Through Evernight he back was borne
on black and roaring waves that ran
o'er leagues unlit and foundered shores
that drowned before the Days began,
until he heard on strands of pearl
where ends the world the music long,
where ever-foaming billows roll
the yellow gold and jewels wan.
He saw the Mountain silent rise
where twilight lies upon the knees
of Valinor, and Eldamar
beheld afar beyond the seas.
A wanderer escaped from night
to haven white he came at last,
to Elvenhome the green and fair
where keen the air, where pale as glass
beneath the Hill of Ilmarin
a-glimmer in a valley sheer
the lamplit towers of Tirion
are mirrored on the Shadowmere.

He tarried there from errantry,
and melodies they taught to him,
and sages old him marvels told,
and harps of gold they brought to him.
They clothed him then in elven-white,
and seven lights before him sent,
as through the Calacirian
to hidden land forlorn he went.
He came unto the timeless halls
where shining fall the countless years,
and endless reigns the Elder King
in Ilmarin on Mountain sheer;
and words unheard were spoken then
of folk of Men and Elven-kin,
beyond the world were visions showed
forbid to those that dwell therein.

A ship then new they built for him
of mithril and of elven-glass
with shining prow; no shaven oar
nor sail she bore on silver mast:
the Silmaril as lantern light
and banner bright with living flame
to gleam thereon by Elbereth
herself was set, who thither came
and wings immortal made for him,
and laid on him undying doom,
to sail the shoreless skies and come
behind the Sun and light of Moon.

quote: As the hound follows the hare, never ceasing in its running, ever drawing nearer in the chase, with unhurrying and imperturbed pace, so does God follow the fleeing soul by His Divine grace. And though in sin or in human love, away from God it seeks to hide itself, Divine grace follows after, unwearyingly follows ever after, till the soul feels its pressure forcing it to turn to Him alone in that never ending pursuit.

Even if the soul tries to hide or escape through sin or worldly attachments, God's grace follows tirelessly and persistently. This unwavering pursuit continues until the soul eventually feels the gentle but undeniable pressure of God's grace, leading it to turn back and surrender to Him alone.

quote: Sam looked at his master with approval, but also with surprise: there was a look in his face and a tone in his voice that he had not known before. It had always been a notion of his that the kindness of dear Mr. Frodo was of such a high degree that it must imply a fair measure of blindness. Gollum in his own way, and with much more excuse as his acquaintance was much briefer, may have made a similar mistake, confusing kindness and blindness. At any rate this speech abashed and terrified him.

quote: Many children make up, or begin to make up, imaginary languages. I have been at it since I could write. But I have never stopped, and of course, as a professional philologist (especially interested in linguistic aesthetics), I have changed in taste, improved in theory, and probably in craft. Behind my stories is now a nexus of languages (mostly only structurally sketched). But to those creatures which in English I call misleadingly Elvesfn11 are assigned two related languages more nearly completed, whose history is written, and whose forms (representing two different sides of my own linguistic taste) are deduced scientifically from a common origin. Out of these languages are made nearly all the names that appear in my legends. This gives a certain character (a cohesion, a consistency of linguistic style, and an illusion of historicity) to the nomenclature, or so I believe, that is markedly lacking in other comparable things. Not all will feel this as important as I do, since I am cursed by acute sensibility in such matters.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Many children make up, or begin to make up, imaginary languages. I have been at it since I could write. But I have never stopped, and of course, as a professional philologist (especially interested in linguistic aesthetics), I have changed in taste, improved in theory, and probably in craft. Behind my stories is now a nexus of languages (mostly only structurally sketched). But to those creatures which in English I call misleadingly Elvesfn11 are assigned two related languages more nearly completed, whose history is written, and whose forms (representing two different sides of my own linguistic taste) are deduced scientifically from a common origin. Out of these languages are made nearly all the names that appear in my legends. This gives a certain character (a cohesion, a consistency of linguistic style, and an illusion of historicity) to the nomenclature, or so I believe, that is markedly lacking in other comparable things. Not all will feel this as important as I do, since I am cursed by acute sensibility in such matters.
summary: The author explains that, like many children, he began creating imaginary languages at a young age and continued doing so throughout his life. As a professional language expert, his skills in this area grew and refined over time. He reveals that his stories are deeply rooted in a network of these invented languages, particularly two highly developed ones specifically for his Elves, which have a detailed history and are scientifically derived from a shared origin. These languages are the source for almost all the names in his legends, a practice he believes gives his work a unique consistency, coherence, and a strong sense of historical realism that is often missing in other fantasy works. He acknowledges that not everyone will find this linguistic depth as important as he does, given his personal acute sensitivity to such matters.

quote: Then Fëanor ran from the Ring of Doom, and fled into the night; for his father was dearer to him than the Light of Valinor or the peerless works of his hands; and who among sons, of Elves or of Men, have held their fathers of greater worth?

summary: Fëanor quickly left the Ring of Doom and disappeared into the darkness, driven by his immense love for his father. quote: We must walk open-eyed into that trap, with courage, but small hope for ourselves. quote: But for all this Death did not depart from the land, rather it came sooner and more often, and in many dreadful guises. For whereas aforetime men had grown slowly old, and had laid them down in the end to sleep, when they were weary at last of the world, now madness and sickness assailed them; and yet they were afraid to die and go out into the dark, the realm of the lord that they had taken; and they cursed themselves in their agony. And men took weapons in those days and slew one another for little cause; for they were become quick to anger, and Sauron, or those whom he had bound to himself, went about the land setting man against man, so that the people murmured against the King and he lords, or against any that had aught that they had not; and the men of power took cruel revenge.

People grew quick to anger, killing each other for minor reasons. Sauron, or those loyal to him, actively sowed discord, turning people against their King, lords, or anyone who had more than them, leading to cruel revenge from those in power.

quote:
Over the land there lies a long shadow,
westward reaching wings of darkness.
The Tower trembles; to the tombs of kings
doom approaches. The Dead awaken;
for the hour is come for the oathbreakers:
at the Stone of Erech they shall stand again
and hear there a horn in the hills ringing.
Whose shall the horn be? Who shall call them
from the grey twilight, the forgotten people?
The heir of him to whom the oath they swore.
From the North shall he come, need shall drive him:
he shall pass the Door to the Paths of the Dead.

As this doom nears, a group of dead people, known as 'oathbreakers' because they broke a past promise, are awakening. They are destined to gather at the Stone of Erech, where they will be called by a horn. The one who will summon them is the rightful heir of the person they originally swore their oath to. This heir will come from the North, driven by urgent need, and must bravely enter the perilous 'Paths of the Dead' to reach them.

quote: No hill was so tall that it stayed my tread.

quote: Bilbo had never seen or imagined anything of the kind. They were high up in a narrow place, with a dreadful fall into a dim valley at one side of them. There they were sheltering under a hanging rock for the night, and he lay beneath a blanket and shook from head to toe. When he peeped out in the lightning-flashes, he saw that across the valley the stone-giants were out, and were hurling rocks at one another for a game, and catching them, and tossing them down into the darkness where they smashed among the trees far below, or splintered into little bits with a bang. Then came a wind and a rain, and the wind whipped the rain and the hail about in every direction, so that an overhanging rock was no protection at all. Soon they were getting drenched and their ponies were standing with their heads down and their tails between their legs, and some of them were whinnying with fright. They could hear the giants guffawing and shouting all over the mountainsides.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Bilbo had never seen or imagined anything of the kind. They were high up in a narrow place, with a dreadful fall into a dim valley at one side of them. There they were sheltering under a hanging rock for the night, and he lay beneath a blanket and shook from head to toe. When he peeped out in the lightning-flashes, he saw that across the valley the stone-giants were out, and were hurling rocks at one another for a game, and catching them, and tossing them down into the darkness where they smashed among the trees far below, or splintered into little bits with a bang. Then came a wind and a rain, and the wind whipped the rain and the hail about in every direction, so that an overhanging rock was no protection at all. Soon they were getting drenched and their ponies were standing with their heads down and their tails between their legs, and some of them were whinnying with fright. They could hear the giants guffawing and shouting all over the mountainsides.
summary: Bilbo experienced a terrifying night high in the mountains, a place unlike anything he had ever seen. Shaking with fear, he watched as massive stone-giants across the valley played a dangerous game, throwing huge rocks at each other that smashed into the darkness below. To make matters worse, a fierce storm of wind, rain, and hail swept through, drenching everyone and leaving their ponies terrified and whinnying. All the while, the loud roars and laughter of the giants echoed through the mountains, adding to their dread.

quote: When heads are at a loss bodies must serve.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: When heads are at a loss bodies must serve.
summary: This saying means that when intellectual effort, planning, or leadership fails to find a solution, then practical action and physical work become necessary. It suggests that if thinking or strategizing doesn't yield results, the only option left is to put in the effort and get things done through direct involvement. Essentially, when the mind is stumped and ideas run out, it's time to stop thinking and start doing.

quote: It was often said (in other families) that long ago one of the Took ancestors must have taken a fairy wife. That was, of course, absurd, but certainly there was still something not entirely hobbitlike about them, and once in a while members of the Took-clan would go and have adventures. They discreetly disappeared, and the family hushed it up; but the fact remained that the Tooks were not as respectable as the Bagginses, though they were undoubtedly richer.

summary: The Took family was known for being unusual and not entirely typical hobbits. People often rumored, though it was absurd, that one of their ancestors might have married a fairy, which explained their less conventional nature. Unlike other hobbits, members of the Took clan would occasionally disappear to have adventures, and their family would discreetly cover it up. As a result, even though the Tooks were undoubtedly richer than the Bagginses, they were generally considered less respectable.

quote: Hump, well! I wonder (if we survive this war) if there will be any niche, even of sufferance, left for reactionary back numbers like me (and you). The bigger things get the smaller and duller or flatter the globe gets. It is getting to be all one blasted little provincial suburb. When they have introduced American sanitation, moral pep, feminism, and mass production throughout the Near East, Middle East, Far East, U.S.S.R., Hither Further and Inner Mumbo-land, Gondhwanaland, Lhasa, and the villages of the darkest Berkshire, how happy we shall be. At any rate it ought to cut down on travel. There will be nowhere to go. So people will (I opine) go all the faster. Colllie Knox says 1/8 of the world's population speaks 'English', and that is the biggest language group. if true, damn shame__ say I. May the curse of Babel strike at all their tongues till they can only say 'baa baa'. It would mean much the same. I think I shall have to refuse to speak anything but Old Mercian.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Hump, well! I wonder (if we survive this war) if there will be any niche, even of sufferance, left for reactionary back numbers like me (and you). The bigger things get the smaller and duller or flatter the globe gets. It is getting to be all one blasted little provincial suburb. When they have introduced American sanitation, moral pep, feminism, and mass production throughout the Near East, Middle East, Far East, U.S.S.R., Hither Further and Inner Mumbo-land, Gondhwanaland, Lhasa, and the villages of the darkest Berkshire, how happy we shall be. At any rate it ought to cut down on travel. There will be nowhere to go. So people will (I opine) go all the faster. Colllie Knox says 1/8 of the world's population speaks 'English', and that is the biggest language group. if true, damn shame__ say I. May the curse of Babel strike at all their tongues till they can only say 'baa baa'. It would mean much the same. I think I shall have to refuse to speak anything but Old Mercian.
summary: The speaker, an old-fashioned individual, expresses deep concern about fitting into a post-war world that is rapidly becoming uniform and uninteresting. They lament that globalization, driven by the spread of American culture—including its sanitation, moral attitudes, feminism, and mass production—is making the entire world feel like one bland suburb, leaving no unique places left to explore. Furthermore, they are dismayed by the dominance of English, wishing for a return to linguistic diversity, even satirically suggesting people should only say "baa baa." As an act of rebellion against this conformity, the speaker declares they will only speak an obscure, ancient dialect.

quote: Es cierto que el mundo esta colmado de peligros y que hay en él sitios lóbregos, pero hay también cosas hermosas y aunque en todas partes el amor está unido hoy a la aflicción, no por eso es menos poderoso.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Es cierto que el mundo esta colmado de peligros y que hay en él sitios lóbregos, pero hay también cosas hermosas y aunque en todas partes el amor está unido hoy a la aflicción, no por eso es menos poderoso.
summary: This quote acknowledges that the world is indeed full of dangers and dark places. However, it also emphasizes that there are beautiful things to be found. Furthermore, it points out that even though love everywhere is currently linked with sorrow or pain, its power is not diminished by this connection.

quote: Who are you, Master?’ he asked. ‘Eh, what?’ said Tom sitting up, and his eyes glinting in the gloom. ‘Don’t you know my name yet? That’s the only answer. Tell me, who are you, alone, yourself and nameless?
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Who are you, Master?’ he asked. ‘Eh, what?’ said Tom sitting up, and his eyes glinting in the gloom. ‘Don’t you know my name yet? That’s the only answer. Tell me, who are you, alone, yourself and nameless?
summary: In this scene, someone asks Tom, whom they call "Master," to identify himself. Tom, surprised and with a hint of intensity in his eyes, responds by first questioning why his name isn't already known. However, he quickly turns the question back on the inquirer, challenging them to consider their *own* identity. He asks them to define who they are when stripped of all external labels, titles, or even a name – essentially, to understand their true, core self when standing alone.

quote: Nay, time does not tarry ever, ’ he said; ‘but change and growth is not in all things and places alike. For the Elves the world moves, and it moves both very swift and very slow. Swift, because they themselves change little, and all else fleets by: it is a grief to them. Slow, because they do not count the running years, not for themselves. The passing seasons are but ripples ever repeated in the long long stream. Yet beneath the Sun all things must wear to an end at last.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Nay, time does not tarry ever, ’ he said; ‘but change and growth is not in all things and places alike. For the Elves the world moves, and it moves both very swift and very slow. Swift, because they themselves change little, and all else fleets by: it is a grief to them. Slow, because they do not count the running years, not for themselves. The passing seasons are but ripples ever repeated in the long long stream. Yet beneath the Sun all things must wear to an end at last.
summary: Time is always moving forward, but not everything changes or grows at the same speed. For Elves, time feels both incredibly fast and incredibly slow. It feels fast because they themselves change very little, so they constantly see everything else around them—like the world and other beings—pass by quickly and perish, which causes them great sadness. Yet, it also feels slow because they don't personally count the years or feel time passing for themselves; the seasons are merely endless, repeating patterns in a very long, continuous flow. Despite their long lives, the quote reminds us that eventually, everything under the sun must come to an end.

quote:
I might disagree with them, but accept that they have some purpose to play in God’s larger plan,

Then Iluvatar arose, and the Ainur perceived that he smiled; and he lifted up his left hand, and a new theme began amid the storm, like and yet unlike to the former theme, and it gathered power and had new beauty. But the discord of Melkor rose in uproar and contended with it, and again there was a war of sound more violent than before, until many of the Ainur were dismayed and sang no longer, and Melkor had the mastery. Then again Ilu´ vatar arose, and the Ainur perceived that his countenance was stern; and he lifted up his right hand, and behold! a third theme grew amid the confusion, and it was unlike the others. For it seemed at first soft and sweet, a mere rippling of gentle sounds in delicate melodies; but it could not be quenched, and it took to itself power and profundity. And it seemed at last that there were two musics progressing at one time before the seat of Iluvatar, and they were utterly at variance. The one was deep and wide and beautiful, but slow and blended with an immeasurable sorrow, from which its beauty chiefly came. The other had now achieved a unity of its own; but it was loud, and vain, and endlessly repeated; and it had little harmony, but rather a clamorous unison as of many trumpets braying upon a few notes. And it essayed to drown the other music by the violence of its voice, but it seemed that its most triumphant notes were taken by the other and woven into its own solemn pattern.

In the midst of this strife, whereat the halls of Iluvatar shook and a tremor ran out into the silences yet unmoved, Ilu´ vatar arose a third time, and his face was terrible to behold. Then he raised up both his hands, and in one chord, deeper than the Abyss, higher than the Firmament, piercing as the light of the eye of Iluvatar, the Music ceased.

Then Ilu´ vatar spoke, and he said: ‘Mighty are the Ainur, and mightiest among them is Melkor; but that he may know, and all the Ainur, that I am Iluvatar, those things that ye have sung, I will show them forth, that ye may see what ye have done. And thou, Melkor, shalt see that no theme may be played that hath not its uttermost source in me, nor can any alter the music in my despite. For he that attempteth this shall prove but mine instrument in the devising of things more wonderful, which he himself hath not imagined.’

Then the Ainur were afraid, and they did not yet comprehend the words that were said to them; and Melkor was filled with shame, of which came secret anger. But Iluvatar arose in splendour, and he went forth from the fair regions that he had made for the Ainur; and the Ainur followed him.

In the midst of this strife, whereat the halls of Iluvatar shook and a tremor ran out into the silences yet unmoved, Ilu´ vatar arose a third time, and his face was terrible to behold. For he that attempteth this shall prove but mine instrument in the devising of things more wonderful, which he himself hath not imagined.’

Then the Ainur were afraid, and they did not yet comprehend the words that were said to them; and Melkor was filled with shame, of which came secret anger. But Iluvatar arose in splendour, and he went forth from the fair regions that he had made for the Ainur; and the Ainur followed him.
summary: The initial quote means that even if one disagrees with or finds something disruptive, they can still accept that it serves a vital role within a larger, divine scheme. This idea is perfectly illustrated in the story of Iluvatar and the Music of the Ainur. When Melkor, the most powerful of the Ainur, introduced his own chaotic and discordant themes into Iluvatar's beautiful creation, he aimed to dominate and destroy the harmony. However, Iluvatar revealed that Melkor's attempts to defy him were futile. Instead of being overthrown, Melkor's loud and vain notes were absorbed and woven into the grander, more profound, and even more sorrowful beauty of the overall Music. Iluvatar declared that no one could truly alter his ultimate plan, and anyone who tried would simply become his instrument, unknowingly contributing to the creation of things far more wonderful than they could ever imagine.

It's about crafting things with less effort, more speed, and greater complexity, focusing on creating new things rather than dominating or controlling existing creation for power.

quote: Altogether those were good days for us, and the poorest of us had money to spend and to lend, and leisure to make beautiful things just for the fun of it, not to speak of the most marvellous and magical toys, the like of which is not to be found in the world now-a-days. So my grandfather’s halls became full of armour and jewels and carvings and cups, and the toy market of Dale was the wonder of the North.

So my grandfather’s halls became full of armour and jewels and carvings and cups, and the toy market of Dale was the wonder of the North.
summary: The speaker looks back fondly on a past era, describing it as a time of great prosperity and happiness. Even the poorest people had enough money to spend and save, and everyone had leisure time to create beautiful things purely for enjoyment, not necessity. They also made incredible, almost magical toys, unlike anything found today. This widespread wealth and creativity meant that the speaker's grandfather's home was filled with treasures like armor, jewels, and carvings, and the toy market in Dale was so famous it was considered the best in the entire North.

quote: Even when a prohibition in a fairy-story is guessed to be derived from some taboo once practised long ago, it has probably been preserved in the later stages of the tale's history because of the great mythical significance of prohibition. A sense of significance may indeed have lain behind some of the taboos themselves. Thou shalt not - or else thou shalt depart beggared into endless regret. The gentlest 'nursery-tales' know it. Even Peter Rabbit was forbidden a garden, lost his blue coat, and took sick. The Locked Door stands as an eternal Temptation.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Even when a prohibition in a fairy-story is guessed to be derived from some taboo once practised long ago, it has probably been preserved in the later stages of the tale's history because of the great mythical significance of prohibition. Even Peter Rabbit was forbidden a garden, lost his blue coat, and took sick. The Locked Door stands as an eternal Temptation.
summary: This quote explains that rules and forbidden acts in fairy tales, even if they started from old customs, are kept because the idea of "prohibition" itself holds a deep, mythical meaning. It suggests that breaking these rules inevitably leads to severe and lasting negative consequences, a lesson taught even in gentle children's stories like Peter Rabbit, who suffered after entering a forbidden garden. The "locked door" serves as a powerful symbol for the timeless and strong temptation of the forbidden.

quote: At least none can foretell what will come to pass, if we take this road or that. But it seems to me now clear which is the road that we must take. The westward road seems easiest. Therefore it must be shunned. It will be watched. Too often the Elves have fled that way. Now at this last we must take a hard road, a road unforeseen. There lies our hope, if hope it be. To walk into peril – to Mordor. We must send the Ring to the Fire.

quote: All have their worth,’ said Yavanna, ‘and each contributes to the worth of the others.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: All have their worth,’ said Yavanna, ‘and each contributes to the worth of the others.
summary: This quote from Yavanna means that everything and everyone possesses its own unique value and importance. Beyond that individual worth, it also suggests that the value of each thing isn't isolated; instead, it actively contributes to and enhances the overall worth of everything else around it. In essence, everything is interconnected, and each part plays a role in making the whole system or community more valuable.
